50228: Kami of Twisted Reflection.author: Mode
50228: Kami of Twisted Reflection.text_parsed:
Great artwork, but it doesn't seem fair that we don't get to choose any creature when we sacrifice this guy.

Man-o'-War or Æther Adept (if we want to compare somewhat strong tribal types) cost the same (the Jellyfish is even easier to cast for just a single blue mana), have the same body, and their effect is the same - except not restricted to creatures on your side!
The difference is that their ability triggers when they enter the battlefield. That can even be advantageous since obviously if you don't have to sacrifice them you'll keep their body.
That's not the case regarding the Kami. Sure, timing is on your side. But Seal of Removal doesn't cost more than Unsummon, does it?

This would have made an interesting Spirit that way. Yes, this would synergize with Soulshift - but this card would be still far from broken, so why the restriction to creatures we control?

It's a sad thing that so many Spirits in Kamigawa were underpowered, Spiritcraft decks could have been far more interesting...

50233: Cage of Hands.author: BinarySpike
50233: Cage of Hands.text_parsed:
I used to run two of these, and two Pacifism's in a green/white, uber creature, creature-control deck.

When I first put it in my deck I didn't like it cause it sucked mana up. When playing against a ton of blue control/flying decks, I run this. I noticed this causes a massive strategy change with those decks, unlike Pacifism. Normally if my opponent casts a creature spell I pull this off their creature after their attack phase. (Depends though, you want to get it off when it's going to "fake them out" the most)

For example, I have a Kor Aeronaut in play, my opponent has Aven Squire with a Cage of Hands on it. On my opponents turn he plays Razorfoot Griffin. After the combat phase I take Cage of Hands off, at the beginning I of my main phase I put it on the griffin. Sometimes I wait one turn. In the instance that I actually did this playing a casual-built deck tournament, my friend used his new Spell Pierce on my Cage of Hands and not my Whispersilk Cloak.

Overall: It distracts your opponent from your game enders.

50233: Cage of Hands.text_parsed:
Posted By: ClockworkSwordfish (2/4/2010 6:32:07 PM)
This isn't strictly worse then Shackles. This one stops an untapped Akroma, Angel of Wrath from attacking. Shackles only works on creatures that don't have vigilance, and the cretures need to already be tapped or they can still attack with shackles on it.

This is a good card, very versatile. Sure there are many situations where pacifism is better, but I like being able to switch this from my opponents Leatherback Baloth to thier Terra Stomper.

50247: Jugan, the Rising Star.author: HairlessThoctar
50247: Jugan, the Rising Star.text_parsed:
Time for a design story!

As Aaron Forsythe recounts (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af38) the spirit dragon cycle were costed according to how 'in-color' it was for that color to have a dragon.
Red, being the dragon color, was very splashable.
Blue, while not typically associated with dragons, but with Onslaught's dragon centricness in recent memory and blue's history of big flyers, was also very splashable.
White and black get plenty of dragons when it comes down to it, so they both got off pretty well.
Green, getting about as many dragons as they do flyers of any kind, got the short end of the stick.

50247: Jugan, the Rising Star.author: Gandlodder
50247: Jugan, the Rising Star.text_parsed:
@beerious Splinter Twin would work with this card, in that, when activated, both the Jugan and his Jugan Twin token would get put into the graveyard (due to the legend rule) and trigger each of their abilities. Once in the graveyard, the token ceases to exist.

With Mirror Gallery, though, you would need to have some way of killing the Jugan Twin, otherwise at the end of the turn it would exile itself and not trigger it's dies ability.
50247: Jugan, the Rising Star.text_posted:
@beerious [autocard]Splinter Twin[/autocard] would work with this card, in that, when activated, both the Jugan and his Jugan Twin token would get put into the graveyard (due to the legend rule) and trigger each of their abilities. Once in the graveyard, the token ceases to exist.

50247: Jugan, the Rising Star.author: BongRipper420
50247: Jugan, the Rising Star.text_parsed: Waaaay before I got into Magic, I found this image and saved it as a wallpaper. I simply was in love with the illustration. I had no idea it was a trading card of any sort. Fast forward years later, after I had built my first deck, which happened to be a casual Green Stompy deck, I came across this card. Imagine my joy when one of my favorite works of art ever could be effectively utilized in my first deck. Even now, I still have that deck, even though it's mostly overshadowed by all the legacy combo/aggro decks in my meta, I still get a lot of pleasure out of playing my mono green deck occasionally, even if it can't always win. It's about fun. And this card makes me have a lot of it. It gets a 5/5 from me for that reason alone.

50247: Jugan, the Rising Star.author: Bisento
50247: Jugan, the Rising Star.text_parsed:
Easily the weakest of the five Spirit Dragons, Jugan is the only one I've never had any qualms about killing. Still, a five five flier for Green isn't bad by any means. But it's most likely to be played in mono green given that cost, and Green doesn't have many other fliers to give those counters to--frankly I'd rather see them on non-fliers instead. I play a lot of removal, and I've rarely faced down Jugan for more than two turns simply because unlike the other four Spirit Dragons, his graveyard effect isn't sufficient to scrub the bullseye off his forehead.

Gorgeous art, though. It's a solid creature in its own right and a good choice for Green, but it doesn't hold up to its brothers.

3.5/5

50256: Otherworldly Journey.author: Equinox523
50256: Otherworldly Journey.text_parsed: Hilariously repeatable with M13's Archaeomancer, making her slightly bigger every turn. A neat card with an interesting timing restriction - unlike Momentary Blink and the like, if you are really desperate on defense, you can even blink out an opposing creature to prevent them from attacking when your opponent is on their "declare attackers" phase, potentially delaying your death for a turn. Since it returns at the end of turn, the window of opportunity to attack will have passed.

50285: Frostwielder.author: MithosFall
50285: Frostwielder.text_parsed: Does its exiling effect apply even after the turn it dealt damage to the creature?
50285: Frostwielder.text_posted: Does its exiling effect apply even after the turn it dealt damage to the creature?

50285: Frostwielder.author: GrimjawxRULES
50285: Frostwielder.text_parsed:
"Does its exiling effect apply even after the turn it dealt damage to the creature?"
- MithosFall

No. Frostwielder's ability only exiles creatures if they took damage from Frostwielder on the same turn that they died.
Two things to take note of with Frostwielder's ability: Firstly, it's a triggered ability, meaning it can be countered and that Frostwielder has to be on the battlefield in order for it to trigger (also mentioned in the rules section under the Details page of this card). If there are more than one Frostwielder on the battlefield and each of them dealt damage to a dying creature, each ability triggers, trying to exile the creature (and they must all be countered in order to prevent the exiling from happening).
Secondly, Frostwielder's ability is a replacement effect, meaning creatures it exiles never goes to the graveyard and therefore do not trigger abilities that trigger upon a creature "dying".
50285: Frostwielder.text_posted:
"[i]Does its exiling effect apply even after the turn it dealt damage to the creature?[/i]"
- MithosFall

No. Frostwielder's ability only exiles creatures if they took damage from Frostwielder on the same turn that they died.
Two things to take note of with Frostwielder's ability: Firstly, it's a triggered ability, meaning it can be countered and that Frostwielder has to be on the battlefield in order for it to trigger (also mentioned in the rules section under the Details page of this card). If there are more than one Frostwielder on the battlefield and each of them dealt damage to a dying creature, each ability triggers, trying to exile the creature (and they must all be countered in order to prevent the exiling from happening).
Secondly, Frostwielder's ability is a replacement effect, meaning creatures it exiles never goes to the graveyard and therefore do not trigger abilities that trigger upon a creature "dying".

50285: Frostwielder.author: OpeeFomenom
50285: Frostwielder.text_parsed: Just thought I'd jump in and correct this bit of misinformation. Frostwielder's second ability is a replacement effect, but it is not a triggered ability. It is a static ability that replaces the event of a creature dying, if that creature would die while having been dealt damage by it. It does not use the stack. It cannot be countered. Triggered abilities only use the terms, "When, Whenever, or At."
50285: Frostwielder.text_posted: Just thought I'd jump in and correct this bit of misinformation. Frostwielder's second ability is a replacement effect, but it is not a triggered ability. Triggered abilities only use the terms, "When, Whenever, or At."

50296: Eight-and-a-Half-Tails.author: Asmodi0000
50296: Eight-and-a-Half-Tails.text_parsed:
Don't be fooled by his WW mana cost. He really shouldn't see play until turn 5, and the crazy thing is that he actually manages to keep up with whatever nasty things your opponent has running at that point. A great card, and his first ability has actually come in very handy when it comes to things like bypassing protections.

He requires a ton of mana to really do his job well, but the fact that he protects -any- permanent is not to be overlooked. He effectively shut down my friend's land destruction deck, and him protecting a lightning grieves/whispersilk cloak attached to him makes for a difficult situation for your opponents.

A great, versatile card, but don't expect him to save you from everything. Board wipes deeply sadden his enlightened heart.
50296: Eight-and-a-Half-Tails.text_posted:
Don't be fooled by his WW mana cost. He really shouldn't see play until turn 5, and the crazy thing is that he actually manages to keep up with whatever nasty things your opponent has running at that point. A great card, and his first ability has actually come in very handy when it comes to things like bypassing protections.

He requires a ton of mana to really do his job well, but the fact that he protects -any- permanent is not to be overlooked. He effectively shut down my friend's land destruction deck, and him protecting a lightning grieves/whispersilk cloak attached to him makes for a difficult situation for your opponents.

A great, versatile card, but don't expect him to save you from everything. Board wipes deeply sadden his enlightened heart.

50296: Eight-and-a-Half-Tails.author: chaoticlivi
50296: Eight-and-a-Half-Tails.text_parsed:
Really versatile card! Haha, as a newbie it took me a while to catch on as to why this old fox is so good. Guess I didn't read it carefully. He's not a game winner but a strong pillar of support for those game winners, since most of the time you'll have something on the board somewhere that you really, really, really don't want dead (or blocked). His biggest weakness is that his abilities are relatively expensive mana-wise in a color that's not so great with mana accel. Also remember that "protection from white" means "protection from your own white spells, abilities, and auras"... wouldn't want to slide off your own Armored Ascension, right? Still, I've been thankful for his presence numerous times.

Also, he's very pretty.

50299: Kodama's Reach.author: DukeofDellot
50299: Kodama's Reach.text_parsed:
Random card... And I play the dickens out of this one... So I guess the fun of evaluating it is reduced.

So, this guy along with the non arcane variant cultivate can be rather potent in games you expect to go into the higher mana zones, such as EDH, or formats that land drops get scary to deal with, such as draft.

Something to think about, when you're running nothing but basics, this guy will nab you exactly what you need. Casting this spell ensures you won't be worrying about mana (unless you need to get to seven or higher) and if you draft two of them, you can almost comfortably build a three color deck.

Rating:
Pauper-Possible if you want to cast something big or play three colors.
Modern-Maybe, I wouldn't though, the decks with acceleration I like (and have seen do well) want to grab nonbasics.
EDH-Yes. Every five color deck loves this guy, as do three colored decks with green in them.
Draft-Second Pick, if there's not a card that will win you the game in the pack, this is likely what I'd grab.

50300: Imi Statue.author: GrimjawxRULES
50300: Imi Statue.text_parsed:
Regarding the affinity deck, there was really only two choices: Ban the deck or create some even more overpowered artifact hosing. I'm glad they went with the first option, as the latter would've probably destroyed any chance of artifacts ever being played again.

Imi Statue may have failed its original purpose, but it still does a pretty decent job at hosing non-affinity artifact decks such as Modular, Esper and other creature based strategies. It also has some pretty sweet art and a very intriguing flavor text.

50300: Imi Statue.author: blurrymadness
50300: Imi Statue.text_parsed:
If they wanted to hose affinity they should've made a more specific hoser.

instant or sorcery - "All +1/+1 counters become -1/-1 counters until end of turn" or "0/0 counters" or some such
artifact -"Whenever an artifact is sacrificed, its controller loses 2 life"
enchantment - "All artifacts become non artifacts"

All of these would work, have strange implications, and generally would've nerfed the deck. This one misses the issue entirely because affinity didn't need to untap much..

I'd play this in a black and blue deck, but not mono blue, unless, as Ignasier and Tiggurix said, I was using the extra land for landfall or retrace or something. Blue has so many other card drawing mechanics that I don't need to bounce land to my hand and discard a card to get a draw.

3/5

50308: Orochi Ranger.author: Twitchiopolis

50311: Kami of the Waning Moon.author: Aaron_Forsythe
50311: Kami of the Waning Moon.text_parsed:
Aaronâ€™s Random Card Comment of the Day #52, 1/5/11

This card ended up in a spot that is unappealing looking, but typically necessary for limited play in a set with linear themes like Spirit/Arcane. I typically donâ€™t like cards like this, meaning ones that youâ€™d be hesitant to play outside of limited, even in a budget black â€œspiritcraftâ€ deck, which is the only deck it could possibly go into. We still make narrow cards for linear limited strategies that arenâ€™t very powerful on their ownâ€”Golden Urn from Scars of Mirrodin leaps to mind, as an example of a card that you sometimes play in dedicated metalcraft decks, but rarely at any other timeâ€”but ideally they donâ€™t look overcosted and have some appeal to casual deckbuilders. I could see people having fun with Golden Urn in a constructed deck with Trinket Mage and proliferate, but I canâ€™t see any particularly happy moments coming from this Kami.

That said, its text box went through some interesting changes during the design and development of Champions of Kamigawa:

1) : Target creature gains fear until end of turn.

It started out as a 1/1 Rat Cleric with the name â€œWitch Doctor.â€

2) Flying
Sacrifice CARDNAME: Target creature gets +1/+1 and gains fear until end of turn.

It quickly became a Spirit that could be used for evasion or to win a fight.

3) Flying
Sacrifice CARDNAME: Target creature gains fear until end of turn.

The +1/+1 was removed because it was playing too often like a green card.

4) Flying
Whenever you play a spirit or mystic spell, target creature gains fear until end of turn.

The set was lacking in â€œspiritcraftâ€ triggers, so it was changed to this. It also went from to , remaining 1/1. Note that Arcane was called â€œmysticâ€.

5) Flying
Attuned â€” Target creature gains fear until end of turn (Whenever you play a spirit or mystic spell, target creature gains fear until end of turn.)

We tried making â€œspiritcraftâ€ a keywordâ€”â€œattunedâ€. Note that we hadnâ€™t embraced the idea of ability words at this point in Magicâ€™s history. This is a particularly atrocious attempt at a template because all the rules text is repeated in reminder text.

6) Flying
Attuned â€” Target creature gains fear until end of turn (Whenever you play a spirit or mystic spell you may do the attuned effect.)

Hereâ€™s an attempt at shortening the reminder text and making it something that could be the same on all cards.

7) Flying
Attuned â€” Target creature gains fear until end of turn. (Whenever you play a spirit or Arcane spell you may do the attuned effect.)

â€œMysticâ€ became â€œArcaneâ€.

8) Flying
Tatari â€” Target creature gains fear until end of turn. (Whenever you play a spirit or Arcane spell you may do the tatari effect.)

â€œAttunedâ€ became â€œtatari,â€ a Jápanese word meaning â€œcurse.â€

9) Flying
Sacrifice CARDNAME: Target creature gains fear until end of turn.

Back to this and ? What? A late change of heart?

10) Flying
Whenever you play a Spirit or Arcane spell, target creature gains fear until end of turn.

Finally during editing it was changed back to this abilityâ€”no keywordâ€”and a mana cost of .

Thatâ€™s a lot of work on what I consider an essentially forgettable card. And this â€œCard of the Dayâ€ entry is quite long as well for what I consider an essentially forgettable card, so Iâ€™m out.

50311: Kami of the Waning Moon.author: willpell
50311: Kami of the Waning Moon.text_parsed:
'Note that Arcane was called â€œmysticâ€.'

I don't know why either of those names were ever even considered, as nothing about them suggests spirits. Off the top of my head, I can come up with "spiritual", "etheric", "gnostic", "ephemeral", and with a mild stretch "primordial". But Kamigawa was mostly perfect in flavor terms (mechanics of course were another story), so I'll overlook one glaring error in its execution.

'Attuned â€” Target creature gains fear until end of turn (Whenever you play a spirit or mystic spell you may do the attuned effect.) '

Heheh, "do the effect", that's a bit too lax even for my standards. I have a lot of jokes I could make here but they border on family-unfriendly so I'd better hold my tongue.
50311: Kami of the Waning Moon.text_posted:
'Note that Arcane was called â€œmysticâ€.'

I don't know why either of those names were ever even considered, as nothing about them suggests spirits.  Off the top of my head, I can come up with "spiritual", "etheric", "gnostic", "ephemeral", and with a mild stretch "primordial".  But Kamigawa was mostly perfect in flavor terms (mechanics of course were another story), so I'll overlook one glaring error in its execution.

'Attuned â€” Target creature gains fear until end of turn (Whenever you play a spirit or mystic spell you may do the attuned effect.) '

50315: Uncontrollable Anger.author: OmegaSerris
50315: Uncontrollable Anger.text_parsed:
@VoidedNote
While I applaud your attempt to make this useful... I'd rather not force a 3/3 to attack me when I have no other forms of removal (hence, me playing this card), Llanowar Elves or not. And most utility creatures can negate that effort by simply doing what they are there for, tapping to activate an ability.

And on your second point, that's what we in the MTG business call a "win-more" situation. Meaning at that point, you are already winning, so this spell is overkill. If you can get to THAT point, why is this in your deck. If you can't get to the point where this card works, again, why is it in your deck?


I could see this played from a general limited perspective. It makes one of your weaker early game creatures able to compete later on. Like ", Sacrifice a 1/1 creature: Put a 3/3 creature token into play. It must attack each turn." And the Flash gives it combat-trick status. But that cost is way below the curve. And I can almost NEVER see this being played on an opponent's creature. There are many better spells to force attacking. Too many for me to link to.

50319: Orochi Leafcaller.author: Donovan_Fabian
50319: Orochi Leafcaller.text_parsed:
I disagree with the first posters here.. this is one of the best mana fixing cards ever. It only takes 1 mana, and then it can produce any color mana from your green mana, which you already have or you couldn't play your orochi in first place. Taking a closer look at the ability, one will notice an important detail, it doesn't require tapping. That means later in the game, you can use this orochi to produce any number of other colored mana from forests or any green mana producer to play anything else. You have 10 green mana? Now it can be 10 any color mana.

also, sweetestsadist makes an important point, the fact that the orochi is a shaman is a big advantage, it can be used with sachi to produce green mana via tap later in the game.
50319: Orochi Leafcaller.text_posted:
I disagree with the first posters here.. this is one of the best mana fixing cards ever.  It only takes 1 mana, and then it can produce any color mana from your green mana, which you already have or you couldn't play your orochi in first place.  Taking a closer look at the ability, one will notice an important detail, it doesn't require tapping.  That means later in the game, you can use this orochi to produce any number of other colored mana from forests or any green mana producer to play anything else.  You have 10 green mana? Now it can be 10 any color mana.

also, sweetestsadist makes an important point, the fact that the orochi is a shaman is a big advantage, it can be used with sachi to produce green mana via tap later in the game.

50319: Orochi Leafcaller.author: dishwater63
50319: Orochi Leafcaller.text_parsed:
i never understood why this was a common, joiner adept was rare, and why people got their rocks off of birds of paradise. this is instant mana fixing, all you have to do is run green in your deck, no weird pain in the @$$ mana fetching, pain lands, or stupid 0/1 flying creatures that only add ONE color of mana to you mana pool.

i played this in a bringer deck along with fist of suns, channel the suns, etc. so i could play anything for rainbow at any time because i ALWAYS had the mana for it. yes, i still had some mana fetching for those "just in case" moments, but for the most part the deck revolved around this lil snake letting me use my forest for whatever i want, whenever i want.

50319: Orochi Leafcaller.author: DjDym
50319: Orochi Leafcaller.text_parsed: This, Sachi, Daughter of Seshiro, and Freed from the Real. I lost to this and a Fireball in a tournament once, after which I have kept this combo in mind. Basically you put Freed from the Real on Sachi and use her manna ability to give you 2 green, leafcaller it up and give yourself at least one blue so you can untap Sachi. Was, Rinse, Repeat. Even if you wanted to only use Freed as the only blue in your deck, it really mixes well with Helix Pinnacle to give you the Hundred manna needed. Spawnsire? Got your twenty manna right here. This combo is the cure to all your manna needs.

50321: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.author: Springeralready
50321: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.text_parsed: There are great ways to use this card. If you want infinite non-combat damage, you can use Kiki with a faces of the past and razorfin hunter. They are both goblins. Tap kiki to copy the hunter, use the copy to kill itself and the original hunter to deal 1 damage to the oponent. The copy goes to the GY, thus untapping both kiki and hunter, allowing you to repeat the process until you can do enough damage to kill your opponent.

@Gaffy00
I think you are confusing Kiki-Jiki with Splinter Twin. Midnight Guard, Battered Golem, and Sunstrike Legionnaire do not combo infinitely with Kiki-Jiki by himself.

Battered Golem does if you include Mycosynth Lattice, Liquimetal Coating, or some other method of turning Kiki-Jiki into an artifact.

Midnight Guard and Sunstrike do... if... well...

Basically Thicket Basilisk with Sleep instead of Venom.

I'd pass. 1.5/5

50343: Harsh Deceiver.author: LordRandomness
50343: Harsh Deceiver.text_parsed:
I mentioned this on one of the other Deceivers, but the point to these was the following: Pay the {1} and attack. Your opponent will likely assume that you can untap it to block with even if the card you saw wasn't a land. That's where the deception is meant to come from at least.

Unfortunately, the cycle simply isn't powerful enough to take advantage of the "your opponent doesn't know if you can play the ability, but you can" thing, which is a shame because it could have been pretty cool.

50343: Harsh Deceiver.author: Mode
50343: Harsh Deceiver.text_parsed:
A 1/4 fourdrop, with a conditional, temporary, once-per-turn-only +1/+1 if you pay two mana,
and the option to make that three if you want to check if you can even get anything from your two mana investment.
Which would - temporarily - make it a 2/5. For at least six mana in total. Wow.

Wizards must have been harshly deceived if they thought this was good.

It's cards like this that make you understand why so many people disliked Kamigawa:
They whet your appetite through interesting concepts, but realize them with such a tauntingly low power level that looking through those cards make it an all the more frustrating trip of unrealized could-have-been awesomeness.

50367: Kami of the Palace Fields.author: OmegaSerris
50367: Kami of the Palace Fields.text_parsed:
I think the problem was how "Soulshift" was worded. As is, a creature could bounce itself back to your hand if it's Soulshift was equal or greater to it's CMC. It's in the graveyard when it trigger and thus, a legal target. So to avoid this, Soulshift was always one less than the host's CMC. By this logic, to get higher Soulshift figures, you need higher CMC creatures. Then WotC failed once more by considering Soulshift enough justification for these overpriced creatures.

Yes, spirits were a theme to the block and had a few powerful additions. But you had to 1) get it in your graveyard, 2) get the appropriate Soulshift creature on the field, 3) get it killed, then finally 4) pay for the targeted creature to play it from your hand. Hardly a broken mechanic. is really the only color that could reliably pull all of those off but it has much better revival methods, so even then it wouldn't have been an issue.

Basically, it was all one big slippery slope that could have been avoided if they added "another" to the Soulshift rules. See Promised Kannushi for what could have been. It's not a spirit itself, but you get the idea. Personally, I blame it on Mirrodin. That unspeakable collection of broken cards was just before this block. I guess it is understandable that they played it safe after that.

50400: Sensei's Divining Top.author: ScissorsLizard
50400: Sensei's Divining Top.text_parsed: @Dohyden: In short, no. Once a spell or ability starts resolving, no one can do anything else until it has resolved. Dredge 5 is all done at once; you can't put another spell or ability on the stack (like top's ability) until all five cards have been dredged.

50400: Sensei's Divining Top.author: oafkad
50400: Sensei's Divining Top.text_parsed:
Jace's Erasure + 2 of these + Anything that makes artifacts 0.

I've won on turn 4 with that, I know that's not super cool but it felt great.

Turn 1, put this down.
turn 2 I put down Jace's erasure.
Turn 3 I cast Cloudkey and said "Artifacts".
Turn 4 I cast a second Top.

Tap first top, it goes to top of deck you draw a card, they mill one, you tap your second top to draw the first top and put the second one on top of the deck. They mill one.

Cast the top in your hand for free, swap it for the one on top of your library, each time you do this they mill one. Then just say you repeat it till they are decked :).

Not great, not a great thing to fall back on as your primary strategy, but it feels great when you do it.

50405: Reciprocate.author: infernox10
50405: Reciprocate.text_parsed:
To be honest, this card has the same usefulness as Path to Exile and Swords to Plowshares, as far as one-drop white exiling goes.
You don't want to Path early game.
You don't want to Swords late game.
You don't want to use this after the wrong creature damages you.
It's all situational, and where I will admit that this has less versatility than the other two,
It's very hard to argue that it's significantly worse than the others,
Because sometimes that other land or extra life you gave your opponent costs you the game.

50405: Reciprocate.author: blurrymadness
50405: Reciprocate.text_parsed:
When I was new I bought a set of this card because it looks like a budget Swords; but it's quite a bit worse. Hear me out:
-It can only be played at the end of combat/second main of an opponent's turn
-It can't hit utility creatures
-Unless the opponent has trample; you have to get hit full force by whatever it is to kill it; which sort of takes on a "Lose life equal to that creature's power" cost; which is much harder to work around

When you see the amount of life this often costs you it's good against traditional aggro (I.E. not midrange) but gets worse the more control-oriented the opponent is. It's probably best as a sideboard card in a Zoo/Weenie aggro deck so that you can kill off opposing creatures as you trade blows. Still; in almost any scenario I'd rather have a Lightning Bolt or a Swords to Plowshares; and if you're even mildly thrifty (or you trade for them) then even a budget player can get those.

50408: Samurai Enforcers.author: Homelands
50408: Samurai Enforcers.text_parsed:
I love this card, mostly from a flavor perspective. They way those villagers reach to them in vain for assistance but the samurai resolutely ignore them. They've sworn an oath to a lord, not to the poor country bumpkins the lord controls.

It goes a long way to showing how easily can become a villain in a setting. If nothing else, Kamigawa was cool for depicting a hero and his attempts to bring down a villain.

Also, as far as comparison to Rod of Ruin, yeah Rod of Ruin is better as a stand alone card, but mix it in with creature type changing cards like Imagecrafter, Unnatural Selection, Mistform Mutant, Wings of Velis Vel, or Trickery Charm. Unfortunately they are all blue.

And before anyone states the obvious arguement of when you combo most cards they become better. I know that, but many cards are rated the way they are, not because of their stand alone value, but because of their combo value.

I like it , not love it. 3/5.

50414: Vigilance.author: Aaron_Forsythe
50414: Vigilance.text_parsed:
Aaronâ€™s Random Card Comment of the Day #50, 1/3/11

This is kind of a funny card in that it shares a name with the ability it grants what it enchants. There are a few such examples of cards like these:

vigilance -> Vigilance
lifelink -> Lifelink
flying -> Flight (close enough)

Of course, there are more single keywords granted by Auras that do not share a name with them:

trample -> Primal Frenzy
first strike -> Lance, Reflexes
double strike -> Battle Mastery
defender -> Guard Duty
swampwalk -> Leshrac's Rite
mountainwalk -> Burrowing
forestwalk -> Dryad's Favor
islandwalk -> Fishliver Oil

Maybe Iâ€™m forgetting some, but in general we donâ€™t match the name to the ability. In fact, check out this one from Legends:

vigilance -> Eternal Warrior

Normally, giving a card a name that matches an ability it grants is pretty lazy and uncreative. But once in a while, as with Vigilance, we want to use the card name to help educate people what the name for the keyword is. You see, the keyword â€œvigilanceâ€ debuted in Champions of Kamigawa (previously it had no keyword and was written out) and we figured the best way to get people to remember and embrace it was to name a card after it. Similar logic went into the card name â€œLifelinkâ€ for Magic 2010 even though the keyword had existed since Future Sight. People were calling that ability â€œspirit linkâ€ after the card Spirit Link, so it made sense for the card that granted lifelink to be called â€œLifelink.â€

Vigilance (the card) was made as a Core Set â€œplantâ€â€”meaning it was designed for Core Set use back in the days when we werenâ€™t making new cards in Core Sets themselves. Funny enough, it has yet to actually appear in a Core Set. I guess now that people know and use the word, the card just isnâ€™t useful or powerful enough to reprint. Maybe some day we'll bring ourselves to dust it off and have it be a last pick, but you're all safe for now.

@Shadoflaam:

It's a formatting error on Gatherer, because Aaron Forsythe's comment gets cut off by the "(see all)" option while in the middle of italics tags. If we were to bomb his comment until it got pushed off the Popular Comments section, nothing would be italicized anymore. If you don't believe me, go to a different page in the Popular Comments section, and suddenly all the Recent Comments will no longer be italicized. Wacky, I know.

50431: Numai Outcast.author: Baconradar
50431: Numai Outcast.text_parsed:
I'd say this is worse than chimney imp.

So much about this card just doesn't make sense. Ok, add 1 CMC because it's a black samurai, fair enough. Ok, don't let it have regen for B because it's a human, not a zombie or troll or anything.

But even given those harsh restrictions, which would make the card pretty bad anyway, it should only be, say, CMC 3 1/1 bushido 2 with regen for 1B, or 0 mana and 3 life or something.

Seriously, what happened with this card? It's not just that it's bad, it's also /bizarre/. When do you ever seen a regen cost like that? Why does black get a bushido 2 1/1 anyway? What was the imagined purpose of this card, other than to be OBVIOUSLY bad?

Maybe that's it. Maybe they realised it was a bit naughty making cards that look good to newbies but are actually terrible, like wooden sphere, and decided to make a card that was offputting to EVERYONE.

Don't even get me started on the fact that this is uncommon. I guess we should be glad it wasn't a rare, huh?

A black Samurai? Bushido 2? Regeneration? Sign me up. It sounds awesome on paper, doesn't it?

Then, suddenly, this happened. They went wrong at every turn. Overcosted, underpowered, and a ridiculously overpriced regeneration cost. Who would ever pay that to rescue thing? 50431: Numai Outcast.author: BongRipper420
50431: Numai Outcast.text_parsed:
Paying life for regenerate is a cool mechanic, but obviously R&D were overly cautious here. Rightly so, I suppose though. Yeah, this card sucks, but there were quite a few 'pay life' abilities made back in the day that get out of hand really easily. Good examples being Necropotence, Sylvan Library, Channel and Hatred. Obviously this card is no where near the level of the previously mentioned, but that's something to think about regarding paying life and balance.

It'd be nice to see "Pay X life: Regenerate" return as an ability on like an Angel or something. Even cooler if that creature had lifelink.
50431: Numai Outcast.text_posted:
Paying life for regenerate is a cool mechanic, but obviously R&D were overly cautious here. Rightly so, I suppose though. Yeah, this card sucks, but there were quite a few 'pay life' abilities made back in the day that get out of hand really easily. Good examples being [autocard]Necropotence[/autocard], [autocard]Sylvan Library[/autocard], [autocard]Channel[/autocard] and [autocard]Hatred[/autocard]. Obviously this card is no where near the level of the previously mentioned, but that's something to think about regarding paying life and balance.

50431: Numai Outcast.author: TheVizier
50431: Numai Outcast.text_parsed:
The name, art, and flavor really make me want to like this card.

The CMC-to-P/T ratio and the horrible regen cost make me want to use this as birdcage liner. And I'm not complaining just because it has a drawback. There are drawbacks and then there are horrible design mistakes.

Hell, if it were a two-drop or even a one-drop, I would play this. Just slap on an alternate regen effect (Ring of Xathrid comes to mind), and it would work fine. But as it is, even the ring can't help it.

TL;DR: This could have been good, but like a lot of Kamigawa, it fell flat on its face right out of the gate. Or in this case, right out of the swamp.

50439: Hisoka's Defiance.author: Enelysios
50439: Hisoka's Defiance.text_parsed:
Second lowest rated modern counterspell? Really? Can we at least get this above Vex? Rend Spirit is rated 0.8 higher than this as I write this. Vex, Spell Snip, Mindstatic, Lay Bare all beat this as well. This spell may be way too niche, but it is good at its niche! Those cards are each just awful!

Yeah, this isn't really going to see play, but consider the following. 1.) Limited. Kamigawa has a lot of spirits and arcane spells. If you were playing limited/sealed blue, you could do worse than this. Its Kamigawa, you could do way worse. 2.) Cards like this are necessary. They always put out a hate card or two for each mechanic they make, just in case R&D missed something. at , this card is both cheaper and less color intensive than cancel. If spiritcraft has somehow been a thing, this would have been a good sideboard card. 3.) Arcane may be useless, but spirit isn't. No, its not a big thing, but it has been supported and powerful spirits do crop up in some metas. In the event that any spirit cards become a problem, this is cheap enough as a hard counter to be useful. Its not likely of course, but Obzedat, Ghost Council and Geist of Saint Traft, Kira Great Glass-Spinner, Kataki, War's Wage, Spirit of the Labyrinth, Chameleon Colossus, Kokusho, the Evening Star and numerous other good, actually-played cards can in fact be stopped by this.

I am not saying this card is good, but either it deserves a slightly better rating, or many other cards deserve worse, especially in the counterspell arena.

50442: Sire of the Storm.author: RunedServitor
50442: Sire of the Storm.text_parsed:
When I first saw this card, I assumed there was a cycle of Sires that trigger and do something when you play a Spirit or Arcane spell. Unfortunately, there isn't.

Anyway, I call this card mediocre. You could, for example, play Frost Titan instead, and not have to wait until you play a Spirit or Arcane spell for a benefit, and also not have to watch out for Lightning Bolts.

50442: Sire of the Storm.author: vantha
50442: Sire of the Storm.text_parsed:
Ive played this card in its Hayday and I was usually able to draw 3 cards off of it and attack for 9 damage. Yeah the investment of 6 mana is a bit much, but we are talking about Kamigawa. Magic was nowhere near the power it is today. With Baneslayer Angel and the Titans everything changed about magic.

Every new player keeps uttering "it dies to....." As an older player we realize that not every deck packs 20 removal cards, we understand that players have to be careful to utilize their removal suit in order to win the long game.

50442: Sire of the Storm.author: OlvynChuru
50442: Sire of the Storm.text_parsed: Sigh... people... this card is good. If you complain about how the average arcane card is bad, then use the good arcane cards. The same goes for spirit cards. In the right deck, six mana is nothing, because I've been killing all of your creatures with Nameless Inversion/Crib Swap, so you don't end up finishing me before I drop this. Spirit tribal can actually be a control tribal, keep that in mind. So what if it dies to Lightning Bolt? You probably don't have any bolts in your hand because you've been using them on all my Latch Seekers. Also, people are always so, SO obsessed with CMC:p/t ratio. In this case, that ability more than makes up for that bad ratio. This gives you a LOT of card advantage, because when you cast a card, you draw a card, and then you can cast that and draw another card (unless it's a land).

50445: Kokusho, the Evening Star.author: HairlessThoctar
50445: Kokusho, the Evening Star.text_parsed:
Time for a design story!

As Aaron Forsythe recounts (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af38); the spirit dragon cycle were costed according to how typical it was for dragons to show up in those colors.
So red and blue were the most splashable, Yosei and Cocopuffs less so, and Jugan the least so.
50445: Kokusho, the Evening Star.text_posted:
Time for a design story!

As Aaron Forsythe recounts (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af38); the spirit dragon cycle were costed according to how typical it was for dragons to show up in those colors.
So [autocard multiverseid="79242"]red[/autocard] and [autocard multiverseid="75286"]blue[/autocard] were the most splashable, [autocard multiverseid="78590"]Yosei[/autocard] and Cocopuffs less so, and [autocard multiverseid="50247"]Jugan[/autocard] the least so.

50445: Kokusho, the Evening Star.author: DarthParallax
50445: Kokusho, the Evening Star.text_parsed:
His ability is SO extremely powerful in muliplayer, that I choose to run him with some self-imposed restrictions:

Use him like a Flying Craw Wurm. Just cast him, and start attacking people with it. Dare them to block it and 'bite the poisoned apple'. Attack evenly, so you aren't screwing people too bad. Explain that if you didn't attack SOMEbody every turn, you would have him up to chump block with, and you don't want that temptation. Don't build your deck around him, don't try to make him go off. Leave that up to your opponents to do for you, and if people start trying to exile him, next game use him Spikier to teach them not to do that anymore. So they can choose to either take an incidental 5 in the air, or they can set off a Spirit Bomb of Life Point exchanging that leaves not many non-you people a chance to win. :D


PURE. EVIL. !!! :D

Just have him be that Awful Tension Card in your deck, but set things so that they only have themselves to blame if he actually dies.

Also looks like a Black Slifer the Sky Dragon. Props for that!

50459: Sift Through Sands.author: Vinifera7
50459: Sift Through Sands.text_parsed:
@JJP2D:
It gives you the option to search your library for The Unspeakable. If you find it in your library, you get the option to put it onto the battlefield from your library. Nowhere does that effect interact with your hand, so you cannot put it onto the battlefield from your hand.
50459: Sift Through Sands.text_posted:
@JJP2D:
It gives you the option to search your library for [autocard]The Unspeakable[/autocard]. If you find it in your library, you get the option to put it onto the battlefield [i]from your library[/i]. Nowhere does that effect interact with your hand, so you cannot put it onto the battlefield from your hand.

50459: Sift Through Sands.author: cheesechimp
50459: Sift Through Sands.text_parsed: There's something that bothers me about this combo. Theoretically, each peace of this combo could bring you closer to actually having the pieces of the combo you don't have. If it didn't matter at all which order you cast these spells in you could effectively use the other combo pieces to search out the piece you didn't have. Even with the two weakest combo pieces you can look through the top three cards of your library for the third. Unfortunately, it's not really that way at all. Sift Through Sands HAS to resolve after the other two have been cast. So if you have Reach Through Mists and Sift Through Sands in your hand, Peer Through Depths HAS to be the top card of your library, rather than within the top three, to pull it off in this turn. Perhaps this combo would have been better had the ability been printed on all three. Perhaps it would have been better if it had been printed as "At the beginning of the next end step, If you've cast a spell named Peer Through Depths and a spell named Reach Through Mists this turn, you may search your library for a card named The Unspeakable, put it onto the battlefield, then shuffle your library." I don't know, I just would prefer it if you could use Sift Through Sands draw to help put together the pieces of the puzzle.

I don't know, I just would prefer it if you could use Sift Through Sands draw to help put together the pieces of the puzzle.

3.5/5

50461: Heartbeat of Spring.author: casualhorror
50461: Heartbeat of Spring.text_parsed: All this Kamigawa hate is so unwarranted, like seriously the biggest thing that hurt Kamigawa was coming after Mirrodin's power level and having the cards that wouldn't be tournament level weakened over much. Like as far as great cards go Kamigawa was perfectly fine if not over the usual, it more suffered from the jank being worse than the usual jank. This card is a great example of a perfectly powerful, albeit narrow card. It was used in the same deck as Mind's Desire Extended. In casual, may I recommend Arbor Elf and Kiora's Follower? Prophet of Kruphix wouldn't be bad at all there as well. These are "merely" recent cards a casual player might actually be able to trade for in their groups that really help break this card's parity.

50474: Hisoka, Minamo Sensei.author: Reishyn
50474: Hisoka, Minamo Sensei.text_parsed:
I notice that a lot of the Kamigawa legends are a lot less badass in the novels than it would appear from their flavour text. Marrow-Gnawer is revealed to be less of a crazy skilled Nezumi Warlord/Assassin but rather a clumsy, unintelligent thug for example. But nobody was nearly as much of a disappointment as Hisoka. After all the big speeches and garnets of wisdom across so many cards in the set, the guy turned out to be a spineless, cowardly old fool who hid under his desk while Hidetsugu attacked the academy.

I think the moment that truly made him irredeemable for me is how pathetically relieved he sounded when he said something along the lines of, "It's okay. Keiga will save us now." like a child trying to reassure himself that everything will be fine. He did have that one moment of dignity where he offered Hidetsugu his life in exchange for the lives of his students but even that was kind of ridiculous as Hidetsugu had already won. He could kill anyone he wanted to at that point (and did).

I was really looking forward to Hisoka making an appearance in the books. I mean, look at him! I was expecting a Blue Mage equivalent of Mister Miyagi with tons of awesome philosophical remarks on the Kami War to boot. Instead we got the man who hides under tables at the first sign of any real danger.

50484: Oathkeeper, Takeno's Daisho.author: Mode
50484: Oathkeeper, Takeno's Daisho.text_parsed:
It does an somewhat good job with Iizuka the Ruthless.

This equipment allows in general to convert the activated costs of saccing effects into two colorless mana if you got a Samurai.

Therefore Ashnod's Altar creates a loop. This could turn Indebted Samurai into a big fatty for instance, although there are better cards to make use of this loop, such as spells with Storm effect like Grapeshot.

Another loop with this equipment could be done by changing the Samurai type with Artificial Evolution and then sacrifice Kor Outfitter or Vulshok Battlemaster to something that can finish the game like Goblin Bombardment.

Two Auriok Steelshapers and a Samurai could also enable that loop, but that's not necessarily the best combo since it requires even more cards than the precedant suggestions...

50487: Order of the Sacred Bell.author: The_Murderauder
50487: Order of the Sacred Bell.text_parsed:
Dunno why everybody's hating. These guys are awesome. They were bigger than most other commons in their environment, so it was very hard to block these guys favorably. Plus, their cost/size ratio would have been fine even in a stronger limited environment. Not spectacular, but whatever. And to top it all off, they're really cool and flavorful.

They do kinda look like really buff corpses, though.

50499: Indomitable Will.author: GrimjawxRULES
50499: Indomitable Will.text_parsed:
This card is destined to combo with Bushi Tenderfoot.
1st turn: Plains, Bushi, go.
2nd turn: Plains, attack with Bushi (if Bushi gets blocked, insta-cast Indomitable Will and kill the blocker, flipping Bushi in the process, ending up with a second turn 4/6, double-striking Bushido 2 Kenzo). If Bushi didn't get blocked, cast something else - Konda's Hatamoto or similar.

50510: Sakura-Tribe Elder.author: GrimjawxRULES
50510: Sakura-Tribe Elder.text_parsed:
@SuicidalTendancies: The new combat damage system means that you can't sac him while combat damage is on the stack to both kill a small attacker and net a land.
You can still block a creature and sacrifice the Elder in response to the combat damage step though, so it's not like there's a big difference in how powerful this used to be and is now ... I doubt many people made use of the "combat damage on the stack" trick anyway, unless they were running Lace with Moonglove or similar instant-deathtouch effects, or their opponents were stupid enough to attack with a 1-toughness creature into an untapped Elder...
50510: Sakura-Tribe Elder.text_posted:

50510: Sakura-Tribe Elder.author: Gabriel422
50510: Sakura-Tribe Elder.text_parsed:
Actually, I think the new ruling (with combat damage no longer using the stack) made a functional reprint of this card possible. It's still strictly better than Rampant Growth, and Rampant Growth has been Standard-playable from time to time.

@ Kryplixx Say you're playing against aggro. You go first, and they drop a Kird Ape on the first turn. You cast the STE, who blocked the Kird Ape and then got sacrificed for a land. The STE ends up saving you 2 damage, so it's sort of like Rampant Growth + 2 life, which is already a good upgrade from just Rampant Growth.

Back when combat damage was stacked, STE did even more. Say you're playing aggro, you control a pair of Mogg Fanatics and they have an STE. What do you do? Usually you either attack with both, wait til damage on stack, then pop the dying Mogg for 1 more player damage; or you use a burn spell on the STE and swing in with both Moggs. In either case they're getting +1 card advantage from the trade, as your Mogg or burn spell is lost for nothing (since STE simply becomes another card, the land they searched for). This is a good reason why Vulshok Sorcerer was played, since she dealt with STEs without losing a card.

Basically he went from being really good to really good.

75241: Glimpse of Nature.author: Mode
75241: Glimpse of Nature.text_parsed:
This is in general cheap card advantage in most creature-heavy decks, especially when most of them have a low mana cost and/or got it reduced by other cards, or if you bring some mana accel (e.g. Lotus Petal or Spirite Guides).
But Glimpse of Nature can find use in many tournament formats.

If you manage to create a good deck with many one-drops (or certain creatures that can be played for free, e.g. Kobolds, some artifact creatures or similar stuff like Skyshroud Cutter) this card should be insane.
It also works very nicely with Summoner's Pact.
When playing that many creatures, especially Storm Entity, Grapeshot or Tendrils of Agony should do a nice job as well, Culling the Weak could be used as black mana ramp (e.g. for the former mentioned storm card).
Dark Confident might be also worth using if you're going to run no high-cost cards.

I thought about combining this one with Edgewalker, which can reduce colored mana cost, meaning you can play Cleric one-drops for free. Best part: There are awesome choices out there, e.g. Dark Supplicant (which can bring out Scion of Darkness ridiculously early that way), Mother of Runes, or others like Soul Warden. Unfortunately you have to manage three colors then.

In an artifact deck this plan could work out in a similar way with Cloud Key, Etherium Sculptor, or even Mycosynth Golem.

An uber-johnny deck which relies on that card might as well consider using Serum Powder, since you should mulligan if it's not in your opening hand.

Another nice combo you might add to such a deck is Chalice of the Void and Multani's Presence. It's similar to Glimpse with the slight difference that your creatures will end up in the graveyard, yet this still enables great Storm effects and cycling through your deck until you get the accordant card.
Such decks sometimes also use very few lands only, the best choice likely being Gaea's Cradle. Forest (duals) again can be added and fetched for free with Land Grant.

75241: Glimpse of Nature.author: Dark_Raider
75241: Glimpse of Nature.text_parsed:
It's kinda bad, actually. You'll need to play at least two creature spells to get back the card advantage you lost from playing this sucker. If you're playing storm, you're better off with just getting of that Dragonstorm instead of wasting your time drawing additional cards while wasting card slots on creatures. And of course, you could play free creatures, but then again, you just put a whole lot of pointlessly weak creatures on the board. And now? If I wanted to do wacky things with Glorious Anthem kind of stuff, I might just as well have played a B/W token deck and slaughtered people without ever needing the additional green to draw some additional cards.
Even my inner Johnny doesn't like this card.

75254: Uba Mask.author: Lateralis0ne
75254: Uba Mask.text_parsed:
At Lege:

That seems like it would work well! I think that their cards would remain exiled, as rules on cards like this tend to only have an effect while the card with the rule text is in play/on the battlefield. If a player could cast spells and play lands exiled with this card while Uba Mask is not on the battlefield, Uba Mask would have to state so. There's a rule there, but it's basically "Effects and Rules on permanents are only in effect while said permanent is on the battlefield, unless otherwise stated by said permanent's rule text." I don't know the exact rule, but I believe that this rule is generally accepted.
75254: Uba Mask.text_posted:
At Lege:

That seems like it would work well! I think that their cards would remain exiled, as rules on cards like this tend to only have an effect while the card with the rule text is in play/on the battlefield. If a player could cast spells and play lands exiled with this card while Uba Mask is not on the battlefield, Uba Mask would have to state so. There's a rule there, but it's basically "Effects and Rules on permanents are only in effect while said permanent is on the battlefield, unless otherwise stated by said permanent's rule text." I don't know the exact rule, but I believe that this rule is generally accepted.

75258: Cruel Deceiver.author: Biteybiteybitey
75258: Cruel Deceiver.text_parsed:
If you're planning to play the Deceivers here's a tip, GET IN YOUR OPPONENT'S HEAD!
Lol keep 3-4 mana behind and have a look, see if it's a land, decide wether to attack or defend with it... Then let the mind games begin.

Of course if you have something like first strike and enhanced toughness this is a lot easier, try putting Veridian Claw on (for the first strike) or Accorder's Shield on (For the health and Vigilance) or similar.

Remember with these cards it's always good to have a back up plan, stop someone from putting counters on it or make it Indestructable.
Love the idea that there are cards that really can rattle the opponent if you're good at it.

I for one would like to see something similar put in place in a future set, make the game less about a particular build (I've seen Vampires, Goblins, Myr and Infect/Proliferation decks take the top spots in my area) and more about strategy and getting to know people's minds.

75265: No-Dachi.author: Forgeling
75265: No-Dachi.text_parsed:
Actually Ninjutsu DOES work that way. Let me walk you through it step by step.

Say you declare an ornithopter equipped with a No-Dachi as an attacker.
During the declare blockers step, said Ornithopter goes unblocked for any given reason.
During the First strike Damage step it deals 2 damage to defening player and is still considered an attackign creature. Just before that step ends you activate say a Skullsnatcher for {B} and it comes into play as an unblocked attacker and the ornithopter returns to your hand.
Then during the regular damage step the Skullsnatcher deals 2 damage.
75265: No-Dachi.text_posted:

75268: Meloku the Clouded Mirror.author: Zoah
75268: Meloku the Clouded Mirror.text_parsed:
The problem with this guy is this: he sort of has to be a modular card.

I understand just how cool the combos with this guy can be yes. But, if you never draw him, then just what do you do with all that extra land playing power?

Logically, what you ought do is have more moonfolk. But there is just one problem there: Moonfolk aren't that good as a general rule. Floodbringer, Moonbow Illusionist, Oboro Breezecaller, Oboro Envoy, and the rest of the Soratami are about your only options.

There's (Ovenomancer) and Uyo, Silent Prophet but, still.

So, either risk not drawing him and having a bunch of usles land play cards on the field, or worse, fill your deck up with sub par cards. (A pitty, the soratami were so cool too)

But, even without the combo, he's still a decent card. And perhaps there is a chance that someone could put together a way to make it work that I didn't see.

75269: Kusari-Gama.author: Dansiman
75269: Kusari-Gama.text_parsed: Shouldn't this say "Whenever equipped creature deals combat damage to a blocking creature"? Otherwise the equipped creature could be blocked by two creatures, deal damage to both of them, triggering the ability twice, each of which damages one of the two blockers, triggering the ability again, causing an infinite amount of damage to all creatures the defending player controls.
75269: Kusari-Gama.text_posted: Shouldn't this say "Whenever equipped creature deals [i]combat[/i] damage to a blocking creature"? Otherwise the equipped creature could be blocked by two creatures, deal damage to both of them, triggering the ability twice, each of which damages one of the two blockers, triggering the ability again, causing an infinite amount of damage to all creatures the defending player controls.

75269: Kusari-Gama.author: heardroundtheworld
75269: Kusari-Gama.text_parsed: SBE's are checked upon each resolution, the blockers would be dead before anything else would happen, But since you're blocking with two i would assume the creature being blocked is of high power meaning the rest of his board would be wiped by the second resolution.
75269: Kusari-Gama.text_posted: SBE's are checked upon each resolution, the blockers would be dead before anything else would happen, But since you're blocking with two i would assume the creature being blocked is of high power meaning the rest of his board would be wiped by the second resolution.

75269: Kusari-Gama.author: Kenji18
75269: Kusari-Gama.text_parsed:
Dansiman: Notice that Kusari-Gama deals the extra damage to each other creature the defending player controls. That means that the equipment is the source of the damage, not the creature. Because the creature must be the source of the damage, the ability will not trigger an infinite amount of times when damage is divided amongst 2 or more defending creatures.

This card has lots of clever wording on it though. It says "deals damage," not "deals combat damage," which can provide a lot of fun for direct damage creatures like Gelectrode, Brion Stoutarm, or my personal favorite, Spikeshot Goblin. Also, Kusari-Gama says "deals damage to a blocking creature," not "deals damage to a creature blocking equipped creature," allowing Gelectrode or Brion to deal way more damage. Unfortunately, Brion won't gain you life for all of the damage Kusari Gama deals, but hey, it still works pretty well.
75269: Kusari-Gama.text_posted:
Dansiman:  Notice that Kusari-Gama deals the extra damage to each other creature the defending player controls.  That means that the equipment is the source of the damage, not the creature.  Because the creature must be the source of the damage, the ability will not trigger an infinite amount of times when damage is divided amongst 2 or more defending creatures.

This card has lots of clever wording on it though.  It says "deals damage," not "deals combat damage," which can provide a lot of fun for direct damage creatures like [autocard]Gelectrode[/autocard],  [autocard]Brion Stoutarm[/autocard], or my personal favorite, [autocard]Spikeshot Goblin[/autocard].  Also, Kusari-Gama says "deals damage to a blocking creature," not "deals damage to a creature blocking equipped creature," allowing Gelectrode or Brion to deal way more damage.  Unfortunately, Brion won't gain you life for all of the damage Kusari Gama deals, but hey, it still works pretty well.

75269: Kusari-Gama.author: cadenblade
75269: Kusari-Gama.text_parsed: Brion Stoutarm wont work because he only deals damage to a player, but it was a good thot. i had to double check that one before i said anything cause i used to think the same thing. if he could he should def be mythic rare. another good use for this is to attack with a 1/1 creature which will probably make an opponent not think it through and block it since its easy to kill. just have a card like Kumano, master yamabushi sitting back not attacking and play his damage ability to blast away the defending creatures. also works well with Oros the Avenger, who could(with kusarigama) essentially deal 6 damage across the field to all non white creatures and at least 3 damage to all creatures defending player controls so long as one of them blocked a 1/1 or anything to that degree. Just look for cards that like Kenji18 said such as Gelectrode that can deal damage from a distance. Another great strategy is to attack with a creature that has "provoke" or any ability like it which forces a creature to block and then trigger a damage ability from another creature you control equipped with kusarigama. :D particularly useful against elves and kithkins.

75278: Shell of the Last Kappa.author: DrJack
75278: Shell of the Last Kappa.text_parsed:
Actually, your opponent may target you with a spell eventually. Don't assume that your opponent will simply never cast a spell at you as long as you've got a card like the Shell of the Last Kappa on the table (or a similar one like Reflecting Mirror).

When your opponent has two spells in hand that he wants to hit you with (or you THINK he does), things get interesting. He may decide to cast the weak one first, hoping you'll steal it with the Shell, and then whallop you with the second. BUT you might let the first one through, figuring he's got a nastier spell waiting for you. But then you just let him get a freebie on you... so he could actually do a double-bluff and cast the more powerful spell first, figuring you'll let that through because you're thinking he's got an even meaner spell just waiting. Which spell will you stop with the Shell? Who will prevail as you and your opponent attempt to out-bluff each other? Yes, this is the sort of thing that made Magic: the Gathering a great game!

75286: Keiga, the Tide Star.author: HairlessThoctar

Time for a design story!

As Aaron Forsythe recounts (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af38); Ryusei and Keiga, being in more dragon-centric colors, were allowed to be the most splashable, and as the dragons moved further and further from colors that most typically have dragons, they became that much less splashable, ending in the very green-centric Jugan.

75286: Keiga, the Tide Star.author: Artscrafter
75286: Keiga, the Tide Star.text_parsed:
This whole cycle is nuts with Mimic Vat, at least if you can get the tokens to die easily. Kokusho's obviously pretty sick too (and arguably better) but this one especially pushes my buttons.

With a sac engine handy, this can be your choice of "5 damage to your opponent and take their best creature" or "take your opponent's best creature and a second target creature becomes blocked" once per turn for .

With a Voltaic Key handy, this becomes "gain control of two target creatures" at instant speed once per turn for .

With neither handy you can still crank out one at opponent's EOT and another during your turn.

But, a quick question about it's effect. I was playing EDH with my Scion of the Ur-Dragon-deck and in a last ditch attempt to kill me (since I had dumped 20 dragons and played Patriarch's Bidding), my friend attacked with his Eldrazi. It's annihilator trigger ate some lesser dragons, and then I realized I had Keiga, and sacrificed him as well to gain control of his attacker. Now what happens? Is the attack negated or does the currently mind controlled Eldrazi continue his attack on his new master? We couldn't seem to find a solution anywhere =/
75286: Keiga, the Tide Star.text_posted:
Scion approves. Any of these dragons can wreak havoc in oh so many ways even if they are nowhere to be seen.

But, a quick question about it's effect. I was playing EDH with my [autocard]Scion of the Ur-Dragon[/autocard]-deck and in a last ditch attempt to kill me (since I had dumped 20 dragons and played [autocard]Patriarch's Bidding[/autocard]), my friend attacked with his Eldrazi. It's annihilator trigger ate some lesser dragons, and then I realized I had Keiga, and sacrificed him as well to gain control of his attacker. Now what happens? Is the attack negated or does the currently mind controlled Eldrazi continue his attack on his new master? We couldn't seem to find a solution anywhere =/

75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.author: majinara
75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.text_parsed:
Horrible card.
If you want a dragon it costs 12 mana. And if that dragon is then bounced or exiled or phased out or something you wont even get the sword back.

And if you don't want the dragon but the equip part, you pay 9 mana for a +5/+5 equip which is horrible too.

To be playable it would need:
- a lower casting cost (like 4 or something)
- a lower exile cost (like 2)
- should be automatically equipped on a creature once it comes back to play

But like this? Gah... 1.5 / 5 stars

75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.author: XTwistedsoulX
75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.text_parsed:
So tired of the Token/Graveyard debate...

Tokens DO hit the graveyard, thus triggering "Into graveyard" effects.
Tokens DO NOT remain in the graveyard. Once they enter it they stop exsisting. So you can't target them in the graveyard.

END OF DEBATE.

75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.author: Gheridarigaaz
75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.text_parsed:
I am simply wowed at how people can miss the point of this card...

Compare it to argentum armor... 6 to cast, 6 to equip. IMO a fair price for turning your general into a voltron with a destructive upside... and it's a single card that you add to the deck. Now this, 6 to cast, 3 to equip a lot more lenient for 1 less p/t and 3 mana by comparison...

oh look, an ability that saves it from being destroyed too. I guess majority of people will overlook the cards token-producing ability and suddenly the 6 mana they thought you had up for a miscellaneous boardwipe/counterspell/EOT combo becomes the surprise 6cmc 5/5 flying guy they completely forgot about because it was attached to your commander. Who runs 6cmc counters?

You're welcome.

75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.author: Pongdok
75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.text_parsed: Pricy, but awesome. Turns almost anything into a monster and spits out a mini monster if that seems like something you might want to do. Here's my problem, and it relates to almost all equipment. How does a snake use this? (I'm not talking about those stupid Kamigawa 'snakes'.) A wurm? Any one of the massive creatures whose only practical use for a sword would be to tack a reminder to "destroy more cities" to their comedically oversized bulletin boards? Don't get me wrong. I like equipment, and I understand that you can only do so many talismans and amulets, but I just feel goofy giving a sword or a pair of boots to something that so obviously has no faculties for using it. Wizards should have spent more time fixing auras instead, either by making more that bounce when their target is lost, or allow card draw when they go to the graveyard. I love auras. It feels more like something a powerful mage might do for one of his minions. None of this, "Here's a stick. Go fight that guy." nonsense... I am still giving this sword a 5/5. Please at least give it to something with hands.

75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.author: Kariuko
75291: Tatsumasa, the Dragon's Fang.text_parsed:
The token generation is way too overcosted just for a 5/5 blue flyer that doesn't even have haste. if you play this or search it up with something like quest for the holy relic and then on the next turn you leave 6 mana open, I think you're opponent will notice...

And it doesn't say that you return the sword when the token leaves the battlefield, it has to die for it to return. So if I play unsummon on the token, buum, 12 mana investment crushed at the cost of my 1 mana. If I need to put up that kind of investment, I'll want something gigantic to compensate the risk. Compare to Elbrus, the Binding Blade, for example, a bit harder to turn into a creature but: 2/3 of the cost, has 3 kinds of evasion, almost triple the size, can win the game in 2 turns by itself (3 if you count when it comes into play) and won't turn into nothing over a 1-mana unsummon

@Gheridarigaaz, don't underestimate argentum armor's ability to destroy a permanent every time you attack

75305: Boseiju, Who Shelters All.author: Mode
75305: Boseiju, Who Shelters All.text_parsed:
@ ely_bob: It says "can't be countered by spells or abilities" for exactly a case like that one you exemplified.
So you have a counterspell that can't be countered (by spells or abilities) which targets a Banefire which cannot be countered (by spells or abilities).
Once the counterspell tries to counter Banefire, it will "fizzle" since Banefire is immune to getting countered. The "fizzle" which causes that counterspell to get countered is caused by a game-based effect, therefore neither a spell nor an ability.
So in the end, the counterspell will get removed from the stack, and Banefire will resolve.

Regarding the card itself: I would even reconsider putting it into a sideboard of an instant/sorcery heavy deck (like a burn deck or another control deck, for instance) since it enters tapped, which slows you down a lot (especially in eternal formats). Additionally, 2 life for a single use are quite costy, and there is no alternate mana ability in case you don't need the counter-protection for your particular spell.

I think it's a pity that Boseiju's ability won't work with any spell or even triggered abilities. If it was like that and entered the battlefield untapped, i would definitely consider using it. But the way the card is printed it's not that tempting...

75353: Aura of Dominion.author: OsirisDragon
75353: Aura of Dominion.text_parsed:
Combo with Elemental Mastery and Thermopod. Sword of the Paruns or Staff of Domination can be used in place.

Enchanted Slug makes Tokens x4 unless you boost.

You can pay 1, tap an elemental, and it untaps the Slug with the Aura. Use the tapped elemental for mana, and repeat the token making. Net 3 tokens each go just about.

Sword requires sacrificing 3 tokens each cycle.

Staff doesn't gain you anything without a booster effect.

75353: Aura of Dominion.author: Mirvana

This plus Grimoire Thief becomes "(1): Exile the top 3 cards of target opponent's library."
Pay (1) and tap Thief as cost, Thief's trigger goes on stack, Thief untaps from Aura, rinse, repeat.
This is one of my wincons in my casual mill deck. Its way to powerful, even gets rid of those pesky "shuffle into your library" effects that hurt mill so bad.

75357: Hanabi Blast.author: DarthParallax
75357: Hanabi Blast.text_parsed:
massively inefficienty mechanism for thoroughly mediocre effect? check!
ability that is normally a downside, could be an upside with the right condition, but as
worded is not as effective for the upside as it could be? check!
7 stars out of 0. because I can.

this card is pure gobby nutsness. real goblins, though violent, are not 'built' to organize themselves into the beautiful 3-turn kill decks that players force them into. I consider them to be playing goblins 'so right, they're wrong' because they use the kind of military tactics that win smart, which I believe come from white and blue mana. the opposites of red.

seriously, it makes no sense that a madness deck would want to be as well oiled a machine as an artifact combo deck. i say its BETTER for madness because of the 'random' clause.
discarding cards at random is the best effect to represent deciding to randomly go insane in a fight. you can't pick what kind of insanity you get like its a draft. that would be too logical.
la-la-C'thulhu! icki icki icki pthang! la-la!

75367: Rootrunner.author: Mode
75367: Rootrunner.text_parsed:
This makes a very interesting softlock with Gift of Immortality.
Not only that, but Soulshift allows you to return other spirits in the process!
Most importantly, you can do it each turn. So if you have available, you'll eventually Plow Under all his lands!

And both go well with Tallowisp. It becomes even better with Eidolon of Blossoms, which is not only a spirit as well,
but allows you to draw a card when Gift of Immortality returns. That's three layers of card advantage:
â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€¢ Reverse cantrip for your opponent, who will keep redrawing the same land.
â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€¢ You can return a Spirit card with CMC 3 or less to you hand.
â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€¢ You draw a card.

Hana Kami's saccing ability works with the Gift as well (as well as Rootrunner),
and might fit into such a deck with the right Arcanes. Maybe Kodama's Reach or Shining Shoal.
Elder Pine of Jukai and Loamdweller might be a nice addition, too.

And since you're running Tallowisp, EoB and the Gift, Eidolon of Countless Battles works nicely, too. Especially if you add more Auras like Etheral Armor or Keen Sense.
Karametra's Favor can turn your utility creatures into mana dorks, strengthen EoCB and is a cantrip, i.e. even more than just another Aura when fetched with Tallowisp - and it practically only cost you one mana!

75381: Samurai of the Pale Curtain.author: OmegaSerris
75381: Samurai of the Pale Curtain.text_parsed:
Just a word of warning: This only effects permanents, not permanent cards or permanent spells. So discarding or milling a land/creature/etc won't get hit by this. Same with countering them. Only destroy and sacrifice effects will see this replacement effect.

As for those asking about Darksteel Colossus, as far as I know, this should work exactly like Leyline of the Void, just more limited in scope. And the Leyline is what mill decks used to counter the Eldrazi Legends with the similarly worded ability.

75399: Akki Underminer.author: Mode
75399: Akki Underminer.text_parsed:
Far too expensive for this body.
After all the opponent gets the choice of removal, and this guy will be sentenced to death by any little chump blocker.
Plus the comboability of this guy is not very high since this will only work with combat damage. Sure, Whispersilk Cloak would still work, but then you spend to let your opponent take one damage and sacrifice a permanent. Not worth the trouble if you ask me.
If this ability would actually trigger with any damage i would consider using him in a Shaman deck with Thornbite Staff, but unfortunately it doesn't :(

Sure, that would have been one hell of a card if he was a two-drop only, but if they're going to raise the mana cost they shouldn't forget about giving him a bigger body as well... 2/3 at the same cost would have made him playable i guess.

Compare him to Ashling, the Extinguisher for example. That's how such a card should rather look like.

75399: Akki Underminer.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
75399: Akki Underminer.text_parsed:
The goblin has a weak body and a high mana cost, which is pretty bad, but he's got a rather strong ability tied to him. I don't think reducing his CMC is a good idea - you don't want repeatable "make defending player sacrifice a permanent" coming into the game too early (or too easily), because the faster you get it out there, the less likely it is that the opponent has a fair chance to do anything about it - and in all honesty, repeatable land destruction is unfun to play against.

Look at him - he is a rogue! A Cloak and Dagger will mean that your opponent only has one shot at removing him, and if they don't take it then you can devote your resources to removing blockers. Make it a deck and you should have any number of ways to remove your opponent's creatures and be sure that you'll be hitting with the little guy.

I'll concede that he was pretty bad when printed, but he has more support now than he used to, and I think he's certainly got potential! Power levels and deckbuilding aside, we've got another goblin with awesome flavour (and flavour text!). I like him.

75401: Devouring Rage.author: Radagast
75401: Devouring Rage.text_parsed:
Rather silly - it's a very expensive, offense only cousin to Giant Growth (a card that rarely sees play outside of Limited), that grants you the additional ability to throw away your army to make the single creature larger. So, it is potential card disadvantage (you need a creature to attack for this card to be useful), topped of with more card disadvantage (sacrificing creatures for a 1-shot combat buff.) Oh, and it only works on Spirits.

Yeah, basically worthless outside of some crazy deck that generatres mountains of Spirit tokens.

I have it in my green spirit EDH ([autocard]Kodama of the South Tree[/autocard]) and it works for sure, but still isn't the most exciting play. A land kill with an optional upside is okay at 5 CMC, getting boosts off the arcane is nice even if I have little enough splice to work with.

75404: Serpent Skin.author: OmegaSerris
75404: Serpent Skin.text_parsed:
You forgot Winged Coatl (one of my favorite snakes) and I guess you could count Snakeform as a type of flash as well.

Flavorwise, it seems very snake-ish. 3 mana, you prevent a trade off of creatures. 4 mana, you stop almost anything from killing your creature. The only thing this is missing for MTG snake abilities, is the "hit opponent/draw a card" (see Snake Umbra). But, IMO, that should stay more in or (Ophidian and Ophidian Eye).

A tad expensive for my tastes, but any enchantment (aura) that can help prevent the 2 for 1 weakness inherent to that mechanic is worth a look to me. Still can't stop instant removal (in response of this being cast) which is where a lot of the 2 for 1 situations happen, sadly. A built in "split second" (while remaining counterable) to aura casting would do the card type wonders. Maybe choosing targets on resolution instead of cast. Who knows?
