76634: Kashi-Tribe Reaver.author: Feathermind
76634: Kashi-Tribe Reaver.text_parsed:
To answer that, Alqatrkapa: Originally you could have divided its combat damage among its blockers to incapacitate as many as possible with its ability.
But under the M10 rules changes only deathtouch creatures can do that. Kashi-Tribe Reaver will have to deal lethal damage to each blocker in the chosen order before it can assign damage to the rest.
Thus where once it could have attacked with lure into 3 6/6 wurms and stalled them all for a turn, now it can only slow down one of those three.
76634: Kashi-Tribe Reaver.text_posted:

76638: Brutal Deceiver.author: LordRandomness
76638: Brutal Deceiver.text_parsed: The deception is this: You look at the top card of your library, then attack. Your opponent generally has to treat it as a 3/2 first striker, even if you can't make it one, and not doing so runs them the risk of losing their blocker if your top card is, in fact, a land. It's an interesting concept and the mind games have potential, but the power level of the cards is too low to use it most of the time.

77138: Hana Kami.author: Gabriel422
77138: Hana Kami.text_parsed:
This + Soulless Revival was really sick.

At its core, Hana brings back Revival while Revival brings back Hana, so there's a loop. What made it scary was the Splice onto Arcane on Soulless Revival, essentially letting you play spells like Cranial Extraction and the other XBB drain X spell indefinitely, turn after turn. Complete with Gifts Ungiven fetching Hana, Revival, Death Denied, plus an Arcane spell of choice.

77143: Honor-Worn Shaku.author: Evil_Tactics
77143: Honor-Worn Shaku.text_parsed:
Actually this is an amazing combo piece with Leyline of Singularity and has lots of potential in Extended. It basically turns Umezawa's Jitte into a colorless mana (since tapping the Jitte doesn't affect its ability to equip or use its activated abilities anyway), and it also turns the Leyline itself into a colorless mana.

This is currently a unique source of colorless mana, nothing else does what it does, it should deserve more.

77143: Honor-Worn Shaku.author: GradiustheFox

Caution: The Ceremonial Baseball Bat of Kings may cause you to believe that tapping a Legendary for one colorless mana is a great deal. Do not be fooled! You have to tap three Legendaries just to get back what you spent on the thing.
It hadn't occurred to me until I read a previous post that it's great for Legendary equips and such that don't care if they're tapped or not, and that that Leyline card would turn all your monsters into mana, but... It's still a little tenuous.
Also, because it needed to be said; The Shaku is being attracted to the debris, and for now it looks like their numbers probably aren't going to decrease!
(Small correction; Apologies, it is indeed flat. So it's a Ceremonial Cricket Bat of Kings)

77920: Thief of Hope.author: blurrymadness
77920: Thief of Hope.text_parsed:
Fun little guy. Lots of little spirits work with him, and Death Denied turns this guy's natural card advantage into even more card advantage. Ashen-Skin Zubera,devouring greed, and crypt ghast all work well with him and eachother (crypt ghast as fuel for his bleed, and lots of mana to fuel a T5 Greed into Denied into a spirit or two coming back onto the board; making for massive lifeloss + card advantage on a good draw.)

As pointed out, Nameless Inversion really works well with this guy. To finish the deck, Tortured Soul makes a good one drop, Nether Traitor makes a good two-drop and recurring beater, and Grafted Wargear makes the mix of your weaker and unblockable spirits very potent (as well as this guy.) Anyone big enough can also utilize Nameless Inversion to add damage, and Grafted is a sorcery speed sac-outlet for Zubera, getting Traitors back, activating soulshift, etc..

Fun stuff!

77924: Hall of the Bandit Lord.author: DarthParallax
77924: Hall of the Bandit Lord.text_parsed:
This card may seem like it is trash. It may seem like it is terrible. It may seem like it's all far too much tempo and life lost to be of any good. It certainly doesn't feel Mythic. (Had Mythic existed in Kamigawa Block, I think this might have been considered for Mythic Rarity...though possibly just rare and Legendary is enough.)


Now go back to your binders, look at your creatures, and pick out all the ones you wish had haste for free (as in no mana. The Necropotence Lesson teaches us that life is generally worth paying because it's not mana and therefore fast. fast = worth. it. If you forgot or weren't around for the Necropotence Lesson, you can also check The Fetch Land Lesson, and the Ravnica Dual Land Lesson)

Now put all your creature cards back into your binder.

It may not look like much, but it's got it where it counts. Haste is as deceptively powerful, as Double Strike is completely obviously powerful. (Speaking of which, Hall of Bandit Lord + Double Strike or Lifelink creatures = particularly good)

I mean, we don't even need to look at Legendary Creatures, though they of course push it over the top and ought to persuade you that Wizards, in fact, knew what they were doing.

77924: Hall of the Bandit Lord.author: Ferlord
77924: Hall of the Bandit Lord.text_parsed:
I never gave Haste a chance initially. It was an ability that I thought wasn't that great, because it's a one-time kind of thing.

But since I've been constructing Mono-Red EDH decks (with Krenko, Mob Boss as my general), I've begun to appreciate Haste more and more.

One time, I asked my friend why Inferno Titan didn't have Haste instead of Firebreathing.
"You don't know why?" he said, "Ok, let me give you a situation: You play Titan with Flames of the Firebrand stitched on. If it had haste, you'd attack, dealing another 3 damage divided plus the possible 6 coming through, all for a possible 12 damage with one card."

I soon figured that many other creatures can be terrible to deal with haste.

77925: Blind with Anger.author: SkyknightXi
77925: Blind with Anger.text_parsed:
Keep in mind that Grab the Reins won't untap the creature as well. A moot point when you're planning to entwine it, but in cases where what you want is to get the victim and another attacker to dispatch each other (yes, Disharmony does that on the cheap, but it doesn't have any other uses), or to use their requires-tapping activated ability, and they're already tapped...

Temporary Insanity: Can find legends, but constrained by your graveyard size (Leyline of the Void will NOT be nice here). May depend on how quickly you expect your graveyard to fill up.

As for Ray of Command...remember that it's blue, not red. Good point for Izzet, Grixis, Ceta, Raka, and Prismatic decks, but not for anyone unwilling to splash for blue (or constrained out of blue in Commander).

77926: Unnatural Speed.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
77926: Unnatural Speed.text_parsed:
I found many aspects of the Kamigawa block to be very "meh", but I've got to say - they had a few instances of outstanding flavour text (Wandering Ones). I really like this little excerpt of a letter from Hisoka, Minamo Sensei to Konda, Lord of Eiganjo; it does a good job conveying how the greed of Konda was condemning every mortal creature on Kamigawa to a brutal war.

In fact, Hisoka is repeating himself here! Check out the flavour text for Night of Souls' Betrayal, and the text on Hero's Demise.

78190: Callous Deceiver.author: LordRandomness
78190: Callous Deceiver.text_parsed:
I don't think you all get the idea of Deceivers. You use the "look at top card" ability, then smirk subtly. Your opponent then thinks you can use the second ability, regardless of whether you can or not, and holds off any attacks that the second ability could ruin.

Although I'll be honest, they needed to be more powerful for that to work well. Most of the time your opponent will just mow over you with something bigger than it even when activated.

Not to mention that it doesn't work with this one because you have to use the ability before declaring blockers...(although you can play it to make them wonder if there's a flying blocker available or not...)

78192: Godo, Bandit Warlord.author: Mode
78192: Godo, Bandit Warlord.text_parsed:
Mutatman and Ultratog have a point here.
Even if you grab his favourite equiment for Godo, you'll have a very hard time playing this card effectively in a samurai deck.
Being red doesn't even annoy me that much, it's a single red mana you should be able to afford (although the splash might weaken your deck, though)
Yet icluding his equipment in your samurai deck makes it rather useless for the rest of your creatures, though...
But he also isn't a Samurai himself, which is always a downside in a tribal deck, also in this case for another reason:
Consider that additional combat phases in a samurai deck can be much more useful than in other decks, since
a) the power buffs from bushido didn't wear off yet and
b) samurai can't be killed by blocking that easy, especially against chump blockers they'll be able to attack a second time effectively unharmed while your opponent's creatures will have a hard time blocking without dieing.
Yet Godo's little 3/3 body won't be pumped up by being blocked after the first fight, therefore he has no great chances to survive since your opponent will focus on killing him anyways. On the other hand you'll likely equip him with the grabbed equipment, which could either be Tenza to make him a 6/6 trampler, or maybe Whispersilk Cloak to solve this problem. Or even Lightning Greaves to let him attack immediately, which would you however leave with that little 3/3 body.

But man, shortly disregard everything i said and consider that you're going to put a freaking red barbarian six-drop in your white samurai deck.
Overall, the card isn't that bad, but it could have been cheaper, white, a samurai, or maybe even similar to Stonehewer Giantby letting you equip the artifact immediately to him, which would have made this card quite awesome.

I love this cards effects yet it bugs me to know that it could have been still much better without being broken...

78192: Godo, Bandit Warlord.author: MidgetfaceKillah
78192: Godo, Bandit Warlord.text_parsed:
Godo is good on his own, he doesn't need other Samurai support.

He can fetch Sword of Fire and Ice or Sword of Light and Shadow to protect himself from the enemy at hand - or just get a Lightning Greaves and deal 6 to the dome if undefended. Umezawa's Jitte is never bad neither.

His signature maul, Tenza, is not the ideal equipment, but it can be a great option to trample through blockers and have the Swords score a hit.

Some good Samurai to pair him with are Fumiko the Lowblood who ensures he will mostly go through unblocked, Iizuka the Ruthless who may sacrifice any of these to get CUADRUPLE benefit out of Swords and Jittes, and lastly Taurean Mauler who is just boss.

White likes him a lot too - Stonehewer Giant has vigilance so he can enjoy the double attack too, and fetch more equipment to perfect your defences.

Furthermore, white provides Steelshaper's Gift, Leonin Shikari and good removal.

The joy of the Godo stomp!

78192: Godo, Bandit Warlord.author: blurrymadness
78192: Godo, Bandit Warlord.text_parsed:
Lightning Greaves
grafted wargear
momentary blink (or any other flicker effect that comes immediately back to the field)

Play this guy. Search for the Greaves and attack.
Remove the greaves and blink him.
Search for the wargear and attach it to him.
Attach the Greaves.
Attack.

Then attack again.

:D (I.E. I'm pointing out that if you blink him you can have him attack for the "first time" multiple times. Every blink you perform gives you an additional attack phase and an additional search. By using Grafted Wargear you get to tutor and attach free wargear each time you blink him.)
78192: Godo, Bandit Warlord.text_posted:
[autocard]Lightning Greaves[/autocard]
[autocard]grafted wargear[/autocard]
[autocard]momentary blink[/autocard] (or any other flicker effect that comes immediately back to the field)

Play this guy. Search for the Greaves and attack.
Remove the greaves and blink him.
Search for the wargear and attach it to him.
Attach the Greaves.
Attack.

Then attack again.

:D (I.E. I'm pointing out that if you blink him you can have him attack for the "first time" multiple times. Every blink you perform gives you an additional attack phase and an additional search. By using Grafted Wargear you get to tutor and attach free wargear each time you blink him.)

78192: Godo, Bandit Warlord.author: DukeofDellot
78192: Godo, Bandit Warlord.text_parsed:
Random card of the day, and it's one that I have fond memories of, so let's get some things strait.

First, RetroGamer3, you are the one that is wrong, read the friendly card, it states that it untaps samurai before your next combat, it states nothing about what can or cannot attack during the extra combat.

Second, blurrymadness had stated a combo that isn't complete, if you wish to perform said combo you'll have to realize that there is no main phase between the two combats, so you never get the chance to attack again before you can "unequip" the greaves. Instead you'll need a blanket effect that gives creatures you control haste or something that gives haste at instant speed... Anger and Fervor do nicely and something to blink him also at instant speed... such as cloudshift, restoration angel, momentary blink...

As an EDH general, you can splinter twin with mirror gallery, and laugh as your opponents scoop up their cards in defeat... cause seriously, if you manage to get this combo off (you won't) you need only attack to get the extra combat and make a new token.

I have seen him used for the laugh, but I just don't see this guy being played seriously... gods... I must be in a bad mood... cause the laugh is usually what's most important.

...

Another comment I'd like to point out, Lash_of_Dragonbreath mentioned Elbrus is black. Color identity counts the card's "Color and mana symbols that appear anywhere on the card" and while he's got no mana symbols, he's definitely black where it counts... by that I mean his 13 pleasurable power and equally desirable toughness.

78590: Yosei, the Morning Star.author: SweetZombiJesus
78590: Yosei, the Morning Star.text_parsed:
It comes as no surprise to me that Mori's deack was so powerful in 2005 when he ran this dragon with Greater Good.

Sacrificing Yosei to draw 5 cards then discard 3 during the opponent's upkeep, thereby shutting down that turn AND preventing the next turn's untap, was just such a powerful combo that few could recover.

Also, Yosei was the most prominently featured Dragon in the Kamigawa novels, so that is a plus for players like me who love the flavor and feel of the game.

78590: Yosei, the Morning Star.author: HairlessThoctar
78590: Yosei, the Morning Star.text_parsed:
Time for a design story!

As Aaron Forsythe recounts (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af38); the spirit dragon cycle were costed according to how typical it was for dragons to show up in those colors.
So red and blue were the most splashable, Yosei and Cocopuffs less so, and Jugan the least so.
78590: Yosei, the Morning Star.text_posted:

So [autocard multiverseid="79242"]red[/autocard] and [autocard multiverseid="75286"]blue[/autocard] were the most splashable, Yosei and [autocard multiverseid="50445"]Cocopuffs[/autocard] less so, and [autocard multiverseid="50247"]Jugan[/autocard] the least so.

78590: Yosei, the Morning Star.author: Splizer
78590: Yosei, the Morning Star.text_parsed:
Let's try a disgusting lockdown.
Take one part this thing, one part Doomgape and a pinch Sheoldred, Whispering One or Debtors' Knell

The result is at the beginning of your upkeep you sacrifice old Yosei to Doomgape at the beginning of upkeep, then let Sheoldred, Whispering One return it with little fuss. All the while tapping things. And NO UNTAP STEPS either!

Great reason to play B/W/G, and 5/5 from me :D

You get to attack with an 8/8 creature every turn and still keep an indestructible wall in defense. And that's not even taking into account all the samurai tribals available in this expansion. What's not to like?

78594: Konda, Lord of Eiganjo.author: Psychrates
78594: Konda, Lord of Eiganjo.text_parsed:
This is my dude.


This feels like what Personal Incarnation could've been. Bushido and vigilance together guarantees a lightning bolt to the noggin every round. Being indestructible means that even if you do have red shenanigans, he'll shake most of it. He's also made for shenanigans, like forcing a block with False Orders or the like and giving him trample or a well-timed fling after the block. He's spendy, but there's more than a few pieces like Grand Arbiter Augustin IV to power him out with.

You should always cheat this card out, no exceptions. In T7 it's unimpressive. In T4 or less fresh out of the graveyard it can be a damn scary beast.

4.5/5 W needs more of this, desperately.

78600: Bushi Tenderfoot // Kenzo the Har.author: Vadoff
78600: Bushi Tenderfoot // Kenzo the Har.text_parsed:
@ultratog1028 Wrong, if you were to assign tenderfoot as a blocker then wait for the combat damage step before casting smite, then combat damage would go on the stack, smite would go on the stack, smite would resolve and destroy the blocked creature, then combat damage would resolve and both tenderfoot and the attacker would be dealt the respective damage they were assigned regardless of whether the source is still in play. After combat damage resolves, and tenderfoot is moved to the graveyard, the flip card ability would trigger, and resolve with no target to affect as tenderfoot would no longer be in play.

If you were to smite after assigning a blocker but before the combat damage step, then no combat damage would occur as the creature tenderfoot blocked would already have left play and the flip card ability would never trigger.
78600: Bushi Tenderfoot // Kenzo the Har.text_posted:
@ultratog1028 Wrong, if you were to assign tenderfoot as a blocker then wait for the combat damage step before casting smite, then combat damage would go on the stack, smite would go on the stack, smite would resolve and destroy the blocked creature, then combat damage would resolve and both tenderfoot and the attacker would be dealt the respective damage they were assigned regardless of whether the source is still in play. After combat damage resolves, and tenderfoot is moved to the graveyard, the flip card ability would trigger, and resolve with no target to affect as tenderfoot would no longer be in play.

If you were to smite after assigning a blocker but before the combat damage step, then no combat damage would occur as the creature tenderfoot blocked would already have left play and the flip card ability would never trigger.

78608: Myojin of Seeing Winds.author: AColonyOfAnts
78608: Myojin of Seeing Winds.text_parsed:
To the people saying it's not the best of Myojin, sure. He's not great by himself. Has anyone ever tried running him with Psychosis Crawler, Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind, Archmage Ascension, Venser's Journal He's a combo piece. And unlike the red and white Myojin, you don't lose tempo by playing him (All your other creatures destroyed, or all your lands destroyed). 10 mana to cost means at least 11 cards drawn (10 lands, 1 Myojin) when you get him into play, at instant speed, whenever you want it. Understandably so, people scoop when I drop him in EDH.

Sure, he's a measly 3/3, but if you're using him for the sick beats, you're not realizing his full potential.

78678: Nezumi Graverobber // Nighteyes t.author: theis999
78678: Nezumi Graverobber // Nighteyes t.text_parsed:
http://community.wizards.com/go/thread/view/75842/24953389/Nezumi_Graverobber?post_id=450497033#450497033
and
http://community.wizards.com/go/thread/view/75842/21973461/Q:_Nezumi_Graverobber_and_triggering_partial_abilities?post_id=380735913#380735913

You can't activate the graverobbers ability without a target (a card in an opponents graveyard) and the ability will fizzle if the target isn't legal upon resolution. The graverobber will then check if it was there is any cards in that same graveyard, if there isn't any then you will flip the card.

That also means that the graverobber doesn't check as statebased action if there is an opponents graveyard that is empty.

So to put it simple: The graverobber will only flip if it exiles the last card in a graveyard.

I was unsure myself, that is why i did the research. But i still like the card, it reminds me about kamigawa and my rat deck^^

You can't activate the graverobbers ability without a target (a card in an opponents graveyard) and the ability will fizzle if the target isn't legal upon resolution. So to put it simple: The graverobber will only [b]flip[/b] if it exiles [b]the last card[/b] in a graveyard.

I was unsure myself, that is why i did the research. But i still like the card, it reminds me about kamigawa and my rat deck^^

78678: Nezumi Graverobber // Nighteyes t.author: fujimoto
78678: Nezumi Graverobber // Nighteyes t.text_parsed:
The ability has to have a legal target (a card in a graveyard) to be activated and resolved. It's all one ability. So, if the graveyard is already empty, you can't activate the ability, Graverobber doesn't flip.

If it were 2 separate abilities then it would flip without having to exile a card first.

Also to those that might ask, no you can't get the divinity counter if you play it with rise from the grave, or some other affect that doesn't play it directly from your hand.  You can, however, boomerang it with a number of spells and replay it a second time to get the affect again, or use that which was taken.

78681: Myojin of Cleansing Fire.author: Guest513736147
78681: Myojin of Cleansing Fire.text_parsed:
People are suggesting Gilder Bairn. Very good idea, as it lets you purify the board each turn. Here's an even better (maybe) solution. In the Elspeth vs. Tezzeret duel decks, there is a card from Scars of Mirrodin called "Contagion Clasp". It is essentially this:

"Pay 4 mana, tap: Choose any number of permanents or players, then for each counter on that object, put an additional counter on of the same type"

Wordy ability, but I like it. The keyword is called "Proliferate". Use this with the Myojin, and get a repeatable Wrath of God each turn (it's even 4 mana)!

@JarieSuicune:

Even though this says "all OTHER" creatures, it still does not target. So Progenitus, Black Knight, Malakir Bloodwitch, etc., all still die. This Myojin doesn't, because it says other, and even better, OTHER Myojins don't if they still have their divinity counter. So get multiple Myojins onto the battlefield, go crazy with Proliferate, and wipe the field, draw 12 cards, discard opponent's hand, destroy all lands, and play any number of creatures every turn! Woohoo!

78683: Sensei Golden-Tail.author: AXER
78683: Sensei Golden-Tail.text_parsed:
Definitely use with non-Samurais to pump them up with Takeno, Samurai General, Nagao, Bound by Honor, and Call to Glory.

Question! If you give a creature the Samurai sub-type, can you save him with Oathkeeper, Takeno's Daisho? The creature would go to the graveyard and then return to play but only if s/he is a Samurai, does s/he lose the Samurai sub-type it gained while in play (because it goes to the graveyard)? It would lose the counter, but according the Magic Rulings the counter doesn't make the creature a Samurai with Bushido 1 (the counter is basically just there for fun and the abilities stay regardless of the counter staying or not.)
Also, will someone further explain the Magic Rulings on multiple instances of Bushido?
78683: Sensei Golden-Tail.text_posted:
Definitely use with non-Samurais to pump them up with [autocard]Takeno, Samurai General[/autocard], [autocard]Nagao, Bound by Honor[/autocard], and [autocard]Call to Glory[/autocard].

Question! If you give a creature the Samurai sub-type, can you save him with [autocard]Oathkeeper, Takeno's Daisho[/autocard]? The creature would go to the graveyard and then return to play but only if s/he is a Samurai, does s/he lose the Samurai sub-type it gained while in play (because it goes to the graveyard)? It would lose the counter, but according the Magic Rulings the counter doesn't make the creature a Samurai with Bushido 1 (the counter is basically just there for fun and the abilities stay regardless of the counter staying or not.) 
Also, will someone further explain the Magic Rulings on multiple instances of Bushido?

78683: Sensei Golden-Tail.author: Kurhan
78683: Sensei Golden-Tail.text_parsed:
AXER:

The ruling on Oathkeeper states that it checks after the creature is in the graveyard, so it have to have the type samurai while in the graveyard. It is understood that all effects that modify creatures cease to exist when put into a graveyard, unless otherwise stated.

in short, no it won't return the creature unless its is a samurai or changeling.

Part 2:

"Multiple instances of bushido trigger separately" translates to
bushido is a triggered ability. when the requirements to trigger it are met it goes on the stack.
having multiple bushido instances on a single creature will cause them to all trigger at the same time, then be put on the stack and be forced to resolve one at a time, not all at once.

Normally there is not a distinguishable difference between all in one or separate, but if someone is playing with a spell such as phthisis and a way to set it off at will means they could set it off to hit between your creature's increases in power and toughness.

of course, if someone had such a set up, they would likely want to hit your fully buffed samurai, not a lesser form....

78683: Sensei Golden-Tail.author: Asmodi0000
78683: Sensei Golden-Tail.text_parsed:
Best EDH general to make friends with. Bushido is better than +1/+1 counters in this case, because if you decide to put a few counters on someone else's creatures it's not as bad if they decide to attack you because they won't deal any extra damage to you, only to your creatures if you decide to block.

And, everyone loves having their creatures become Samurai.

With plenty of slow early turns in EDH, you can pop him out, and either start making allies or start pumping himself up until he's got bushido 20. Sure, you won't likely be able to ever kill someone with General Damage, but it's pretty awesome for a creature to be a mild-mannered 2/1 that suddenly explodes into a 22/21 whenever he gets into a battle.

78683: Sensei Golden-Tail.author: Zielheim
78683: Sensei Golden-Tail.text_parsed:
@Shadoflaam

From my understanding, all the counter does is effectively remind players that the creature is a Samurai and has Bushido X (technically X instances of Bushido 1 if I'm reading the rules right, but whatever). If you gave the training counters to something else without using the Sensei's ability, it wouldn't be a Samurai, nor would it have Bushido X. Which means if you put a training counter on Skullbriar, the Walking Grave, even though it would keep the counter, it wouldn't do anything if it ever left the field.

78691: Student of Elements // Tobita, Ma.author: Aquillion
78691: Student of Elements // Tobita, Ma.text_parsed:
@Arachnos: The problem with this card is that it's just too clunky. Chances are, you're spending two cards to give all your creatures flying -- at that point, you'd be better off waiting a bit and using Levitation or Wonder, or just using two flying-granting enchantments on your biggest creatures.

Also, even once he's flipped, he's vulnerable to creature removal. Not only that, but having him hit by removal once he's flipped will usually cost you two cards for one of your opponent's, since you wasted a card flipping him.

But the worst part is from a deck-design standpoint. For this creature to be useful, you have to include a way to make him fly in your deck (probably multiples, so you can rely on drawing it); but once he's flipped, those things are useless.

There are ways around this, but, like I said, too clunky -- the benefit he gives isn't worth carefully considering combinations of cards to get, not when the whole thing still collapses to any sort of creature-hate.
78691: Student of Elements // Tobita, Ma.text_posted:

78694: Akki Lavarunner // Tok-Tok, Volca.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
78694: Akki Lavarunner // Tok-Tok, Volca.text_parsed:
Before there were Level Up cards... there were flip cards!

Lavarunner is certainly fragile in his natural state, but if you get him flipped then he becomes an interesting enabler. Comparing him to Furnace of Rath is a bit misleading - he is much closer to Sulfuric Vapors, except that he will include all red sources, rather than simply spells. If you want to make the most out of his ability, then, you're looking for cards that deal 1 damage to one or more players, since this little guy will be effectively doubling that without carrying as much of the inherent risk of the Furnace (to its caster). Some examples:

Chandra Nalaar
Kumano, Master Yamabushi
Goblin Bombardment
Pyrohemia (note: this will kill you too!)
Sparkcaster
Firecat Blitz

Remember - this will only enhance damage to players. It won't let Goblin Sharpshooter machine-gun 2/2s; it won't help you kill that Jace either. Build accordingly! =)

78695: Kitsune Mystic // Autumn-Tail, Ki.author: Donovan_Fabian
78695: Kitsune Mystic // Autumn-Tail, Ki.text_parsed: Well, yes and no, simic guildmage IS better as an overall transfer affect, but kitsune mystic has a unique advantage.  The kitsune mystic ability does -not- specify that it has to be -your- creature.  You can steal enchantments from your opponent.  More over, this is an important difference for cards like coma veil, because you can place it on a  new target once a turn, or pacifism.  However, it is harder to get your kitsune flipped in the first place, although if you have a deck with pacifism in it you can still enchant your kitsune with it and then move it after its flipped with the ability.  Also many people don't think about the fact that its ability does not require the kitsune to tap, and when its flipped its a 4/5 creature who can do some heavy lifting.

78695: Kitsune Mystic // Autumn-Tail, Ki.author: Tynansdtm
78695: Kitsune Mystic // Autumn-Tail, Ki.text_parsed:
@Donovan_Fabian: Simic Guildmage moves Pacifism and Coma Veil around just fine. The initial and final target permanents must be controlled by the same player. This guy can steal their enchantments though, and that's cool. The Guildmage can move the enchantments on their lands.
@coyotemoon: You are wrong. Enchantments can be attached to permanents with shroud. Auras only target when they are cast, but if put on the battlefield they must attach to a legal permanent (without targeting it). If no such permanent exists, they don't leave whatever zone they were previously in.
78695: Kitsune Mystic // Autumn-Tail, Ki.text_posted:

Auras only target when they are cast, but if put on the battlefield they [b]must[/b] attach to a legal permanent (without targeting it). If no such permanent exists, they don't leave whatever zone they were previously in.

78695: Kitsune Mystic // Autumn-Tail, Ki.author: casual_melvin
78695: Kitsune Mystic // Autumn-Tail, Ki.text_parsed:
I really love this kind of card, both the flip aspect and the enchantment moving are interesting to build around without being overly powerful. It also changes the rules of the game and the style of game play but without the total chaos of red spells.

Note that while this lets you enchant creatures with shroud, if the creature has protection from white or protection from enchantments or any other relevant protection (wordy perhaps) the enchantment will fall off and go to the graveyard.

Also note the if the enchantment has shroud this can't move it.

I really love this kind of card, both the flip aspect and the enchantment moving are interesting to build around without being overly powerful. It also changes the rules of the game and the style of game play  but without the total  [autocard multiverseid="47274"]chaos[/autocard] of red spells.

Note that while this lets you enchant creatures with shroud, if the creature has protection from white or protection from enchantments or any other relevant protection ([i]wordy[/i] perhaps) the enchantment will fall off and go to the graveyard.

Also note the if the [i]enchantment[/i] has shroud this can't move it.

78697: Azami, Lady of Scrolls.author: Zoah
78697: Azami, Lady of Scrolls.text_parsed:
The only problem I could ever see with this card is that you have a maximum hand size. Other than that, In a wizard deck, she would slaughter relentlessly. Combined with Graceful Adept she would be perfect, assuming you managed to use the fist full of cards you would get to kill your opponent in time. She can also activate her own ability, so she is always at lest slightly useful.

Her only real problem is how delicate she is. If she so much as gets Shocked, she's gone. Although, at two, she's not the weakest wizard I have ever seen.

Other than a few minor downsides, she's strongest draw engine I have ever seen. So much so that I would worry about an accidental mill loss from this...

So, base rating: ***

Deck building potential: +*
Draw power: +*
Defenseless: -*/4
Oops mill loss: -*/4

final: **** */2

I played this in a red/blue card draw, mill and burn deck with enclave cryptologist and sea gate oracle. In every game I managed to get at least 3 cards as soon as I paid and got her out. I gave this a 5/5

78697: Azami, Lady of Scrolls.author: fissionessence
78697: Azami, Lady of Scrolls.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #4 - 6/30/2011 - Azami, Lady of Scrolls

Hmm. Five mana for a zero-two. Err, 0/2. But she can tap herself immediately to replace herself on a card basis, plus any other Wizards you might have put you up more cards. If she gets Shocked immediately, you still 2-for-1'd your opponent, though you're out a bit of mana. Seems worth it. Oh wait, did I not need to convince you that she's a pretty good card?

I don't play a ton of Commander, or at least I don't keep up with all the trends and bannings and 'most hated cards', etc., but I feel like I've heard Azami's name mentioned at least a few times. I've never played with her, but it's definitely the type of otherwise boring card-advantage-based card I could see myself enjoying quite a bit, in a, "You're dead and I still have ten cards in my hand," kind of way. I guess that's kind of a mean way.

For someone with so much knowledge on so many scrolls, I have to wonder if she really thinks destroying the kami shrines is going to help.

78853: Shisato, Whispering Hunter.author: Evil_Tactics
78853: Shisato, Whispering Hunter.text_parsed:
Agreed with how bad the design of this truly is. A 2/2 for 4 mana is already bad, stats like that usually mean the creature will have a VERY useful effect. An effect isn't useful if it will not likely occur, such as in this case.

Plus with the fact that you do have to sacrifice a snake every upkeep, you are forced to play a snake token deck, which in itself isn't that strong anyway. Token decks are more powerful if they are saproling or elf tokens. If it were a 1/3 or even 1/4 to survive Lightning Bolt, then I could forgive this design. As it stands, this is horrible.

78853: Shisato, Whispering Hunter.author: Tanaka348
78853: Shisato, Whispering Hunter.text_parsed: Most of the snakes and especially the snake tribal stuff in Kamigawa was actually pretty good. This... not so much. This seems like one of those cards that you have to make suck to print; if a deck can't block or deal with it when it untaps and you have a snake generator or even just a few snakes to cast for the next couple turns, the game's probably over because you just set up a one-sided Stasis-type effect. And considering how massively unfun that is I can see why this card was made extra weak. It should have just been cut from the file, though, since it doesn't really serve any purpose for limited, the only justification left.

78854: Horobi, Death's Wail.author: solaris1302
78854: Horobi, Death's Wail.text_parsed: Great with Eldrazi Monument, especially in a Spirit and Arcane deck. Make all of your creatures indestructible, so that the drawback no longer affects you. Soulshift for your spirits takes care of the sacrificial cost of the Monument, while at the same time gauranteeing that you get to play at least one Spirit spell each turn. Cards such as Waxmane Baku, Skullmane Baku, Teller of Tales, Kami of the Waning Moon, etc all ensure that you get to target plenty of creatures whenever you play a spell. Get enough creatures out and each time you play a spirit, you get to destroy multiple opponent creatures.

78854: Horobi, Death's Wail.author: OpeeFomenom
78854: Horobi, Death's Wail.text_parsed:
The really cool part is this gets past protection from black. The effect doesn't target the creature, it activates as a result of the creature being targeted so if a player tries to enchant their protection from black creature then it dies. You can use this in a multicolored deck to cast giant growth or something of the like on their creatures with protection from black to quickly eliminate them.

@Solaris Now the problem with Kami of the Waning Moon and Teller of Tales is they are not conditional. You will not want to play your Kami of the Wanning Moon whilst Hirobi, Death's Wail is on the field when your opponent has no creatures. The effect is non-conditional so you have to give a creature fear, meaning you will probably end up giving the Wanning Moon fear and killing him so you don't have to keep targeting your own creatures. With soul shift and a lot of the black cards from that set alone it's not hard to get the kami back once it's dead but worrying about the drawback you just put yourself in can be a pain. In my opinion at least.

78854: Horobi, Death's Wail.author: SleetFox
78854: Horobi, Death's Wail.text_parsed:
The problem with this guy is that when you play it, you're down four mana that you can use to pay for targeted spells and abilities, and your opponents aren't. So chances are they'll target him before he can kill anything else, while you don't have the mana to do much in response before he dies.

Protect him with shroud, or Darksteel Plate, or whatever, on the other hand, and you basically have the game.

78854: Horobi, Death's Wail.author: LeakyTeacup
78854: Horobi, Death's Wail.text_parsed:
Ok, I'm NOT new to magic by any means, but I really want to know this.. What happens if you shift the target of a spell or ability with Spellskite?

Horobi's ability goes on the stack, as it's an activated ability, reading "whenever"

At this point, I KNOW you can COUNTER his ability with stifle or trickbind, as neither actually targets him, only the ability. Even if it did, trickbind would prevent another copy of his ability from being placed on the stack.

But if the target is CHANGED, does that still destroy the original target? Because creature has still been targeted, but if the creature is no longer targeted when the ability resolves, does it matter?

I don't personally think so, but i could easily be wrong...

78855: Uyo, Silent Prophet.author: Donovan_Fabian
78855: Uyo, Silent Prophet.text_parsed: Use sakura tribe scout to offset the land bounce, and then go nuts with the spell copying.  There are also a couple tricks for sacrificing your opponents lands, ie if you have a genju card, enchant your opponents land, then steal it with a roo***er matriarch.  More than likely a sakura tribe scout will do the trick, and if you don't have that a coiling oracle can help too.  Her ability also doesn't cause her to tap, so you can still attack with her 4/4 and flying after taking out your opponents creatures with say.. a forked rolling thunder.

78855: Uyo, Silent Prophet.author: Gheridarigaaz
78855: Uyo, Silent Prophet.text_parsed:
I think she's a nicely designed, well rounded card. In particular i'm thinking of edh. Note that she can bypass alot of the annoying, red, mass land destruction simply by using her ability.

"nice wildfire you got there... "

furthermore, her own protection is partially guaranteed by her ability, so long as you don't excessively use it in order to continuously off people's permanents you should be fine, or if your deck isn't entirely based on being a complete prick so your playgroup doesn't off you at the first opportunity.

Having a decent body along with evasion also means she can win a game through commander damage, although i'd have to say it definitely helps adding in some way of amplifying that damage, just like it would with any other commander. Besides, 6cmc for an air elemental with a sweet ability isn't that bad, although something like djinn of wishes is also pretty neat, manages to do just fine without costing the extra mana. Coupled with a few spells that encourage other players to cast more spells like arcane melee might be worth looking into if you're thinking of building around her.

Let's not forget horn of greed is a thing, which in and of itself, can also lead to quite a few weird interactions with a few other cards like storm cauldron and ankh of mishra resulting in a relatively punishing game for unprepared opponents.

78962: Kiku, Night's Flower.author: Boakes2047
78962: Kiku, Night's Flower.text_parsed:
@divine_exodus Umm, Kiku isn't a spell while she is on the battlefield. She is a permanent, not a spell. A fireball for 15 damage wouldn't be able to target emrakul because fireball doesn't become a permanent, it remains a spell. There is a huge difference between something being a spell and being a permanent.

This is why clone can kill emrakul, because because it enters the battlefield as emrakul.

78964: Kumano, Master Yamabushi.author: Myrs
78964: Kumano, Master Yamabushi.text_parsed:
@ brunsbr103
again, just add deathtouch and you can exile any creature for 2 mana.

No, you can't. You can destroy any creature for , and if that creature would be destroyed (and put in a graveyard), it is exiled instead.

Exiling is a much more powerful mechanic than destroying, and the two shouldn't be confused. That combo would not allow you to remove indestructible or regenerating creatures, while it would remove the cards it did affect from the game.

/end-rant at 2 year old comment
78964: Kumano, Master Yamabushi.text_posted:

[i]again, just add deathtouch and you can exile any creature for 2 mana.[/i]

No, you can't. You can destroy any creature for [1][R], and [u]if[/u] that creature would be destroyed (and put in a graveyard), it is exiled instead. 

Exiling is a much more powerful mechanic than destroying, and the two shouldn't be confused. That combo would not allow you to remove indestructible or regenerating creatures, while it would remove the cards it did affect from the game.

/end-rant at 2 year old comment

78964: Kumano, Master Yamabushi.author: Ansem717
78964: Kumano, Master Yamabushi.text_parsed:
He's a really good EDH general. Useful with anything that gives you more mana, or more damage. Mana Flare, Gratuitous Violence, Furnace of Rath, Dictate of the Twin Gods, Caged Sun, Gauntlet of Power, Gauntlet of Might, Extraplanar Lens, Heartstone, and Quest for Pure Flame.

With all of these cards on the field and active, one Mountain can tap for 5 Red Mana, utilizing Heartstone for R -> 1 Damage instead of 1R -> 1 Damage, then doubling the damage for Furnace, Gratuitous, Dicatate and then Quest, will lead to a total of 16 damage per 1 damage for 1 red. So 80 damage per Mountain. Not even Koth's ultimate can do that. Give him infect to make him kill an opponent quicker without all of those cards on the field. Give him lifelink to keep yourself alive. Godo can be used to fetch both him and his weapon. The deck is sleek, fast, and has answers. Everything RED needs to be an EDH.

78965: Seizan, Perverter of Truth.author: Shiizu
78965: Seizan, Perverter of Truth.text_parsed:
Yes, this guy suffers from the same problem as howling mine: your opponents will draw first.

That asides, he's huge for his mana cost. A 6/5 for 5 in black is way above the curve. On top of that, he's doing 2 damage per turn to your opponents. He's also quite resilient to removal:
1) He's black. Most black removal will not work on him.
2) He has 5 toughness. He's out of the regular burn range.

This leaves the more expensive red removal(fireball and its ilk) and white removal.

Without a doubt he's amazing in a deck that just wants to kill its opponent. Drawing 3 cards per turn will usually give you enough threats to play. On its own he can stop lots of creatures, and with some support(like Dauthi Embrace) he can quickly kill players.

He's also a demon, and demons require some kind of sacrifice. His price is heavy, giving your opponent a 2 for 1 situation. Still, it's worth it.

78965: Seizan, Perverter of Truth.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
78965: Seizan, Perverter of Truth.text_parsed:
It's an interesting card to play with or to play against. On one hand, if my opponent draws it, I am usually pretty psyched to draw two extra cards. If I have some removal for him, that's just icing on the cake.

However, this is an IDEAL situation; the more common gamestate is that I am hoping that I'll draw something to help me kill this thing. Seizan puts everyone on a rather definite clock, and it does so for no extra mana. If you have used aggressive black weenies to whittle down your opponent's life total, then dropping this guy offers the possibility of finishing him/her off without ever having to attack again, for no additional mana investment.

This card is the predecessor of Bloodgift Demon, and both are very similar.

This gets an additional +1/+1 but suffers without flying. Bloodgift only allows one draw per round of turns, but you choose who gets the card and the target loses 1 life.

Personally, I'd say "F**k it" and include both in a deck along side Font of Mythos, Graveborn Muse, Howling Mine, Underworld Dreams and obviously, Phyrexian Arena... and Yawgmoth's Bargain, if you're feeling particularly evil and don't give a s**t about rules.

Yeah, screw you EDH. Whatever, Whatever, I'll do what i want!

78968: Brothers Yamazaki.author: Mode
78968: Brothers Yamazaki.text_parsed:
A cheer for Wizards for creating an alternate artwork for this card.

It's reasonable that they stopped printing alternate artworks from different artists for the same card in the same set. (See Fallen Empires' variations of Icatian Infantry for example.)
Aside from basic lands, a card should in general be ássociated with its artwork.
But making an exception by creating a second artwork (from the same artist) with a distinct relation for a legend which is intended to exist twice was a great idea!

78976: Myojin of Life's Web.author: mgclmnky
78976: Myojin of Life's Web.text_parsed:
question about ruling: if i were to pipe this out using elvish piper, would it, or any other myojin, get the divinity counter?
Likewise, if i were to summon another myojin using its 'remove divinity counter' effect, would the other myojins get their divinity counter?
78976: Myojin of Life's Web.text_posted:
question about ruling: if i were to pipe this out using elvish piper, would it, or any other myojin, get the divinity counter?
Likewise, if i were to summon another myojin using its 'remove divinity counter' effect, would the other myojins get their divinity counter?

78976: Myojin of Life's Web.author: Meuchelmorder
78976: Myojin of Life's Web.text_parsed:
Glimpse of Nature wouldn't allow you to draw extra cards (by removing the Divinity Counter and putting creatures from your hand into play) because you're not "playing" those creatures, you're "putting them into play."

Elvish piper does not "play" this card from your hand, it "puts it into play" from your hand, so you would not get the Divinity Counter.

78976: Myojin of Life's Web.author: Donovan_Fabian
78976: Myojin of Life's Web.text_parsed: The myojin of life's web is really meant as a game ending card, it takes forever to play it, but once its on the field you have all the advantage. You can choose not to use up the divinity counter until its beneficial to you, and you still have an 8/8 creature on the field that can't be sent to the graveyard by a spell due to its indestructibility. If you really want to make use of their divinity counter, theres actually two ways, but your rarely going to need it twice (since if you just played all the creatures from your hand, how many can you draw in a turn? and etc). Heres how it works, if you use Ninjutsu on any ninja, or boomerang, or any spell that enables you to return the card to your hand, you can simply replay it from your hand for the mana cost again next turn as if it were just played even if you've already used the divinity counter. You can also have That which was taken which doesn't need explaination. Lastly, you can use false demise, except that your creature has to be killed for you to regain the counter, but you get it back plus counter for the enchantment.
78976: Myojin of Life's Web.text_posted: The myojin of life's web is really meant as a game ending card, it takes forever to play it, but once its on the field you have all the advantage. 78976: Myojin of Life's Web.author: VoidedNote
78976: Myojin of Life's Web.text_parsed: Myojin of Life's Web is one of the (if not the) best cards I have. I have even made a deck based upon Spirits and Arcane spells, Green and Black. By using Lifespinner, I can bring any legendary spirit to the field, and I choose Iname, Death Aspect. It puts any number of spirits in my deck into my grave, and I put them all there. My opponents always give me weird looks, but that's because they don't know the rest of what I'm doing. I then use a card like Death Denied to bring Myojin of Life's Web and Iname, Life Aspect to my hand, as well as whatever else I can. I play until I have nine mana. Then I'll play Iname Life Aspect. He allows me to bring any number of Spirits to my hand from my grave IF he's killed. I will attack every turn, hoping he gets killed, so if he does, I can bring every creature in my deck to my hand and use Myojin to basically end the game. And if they don't kill it, well that's their problem, four damage a turn unless they find a creature strong enough block and not kill either creature. Even then I have creatures that make me sacrifice. This card is good in just about any deck nonetheless, plus it's a very strong card to being with.

78976: Myojin of Life's Web.author: Kelptic183
78976: Myojin of Life's Web.text_parsed: Actually my least favorite of the Myojin. It only gives you creatures from your hand, so you need to have the advantage anyway for it to be effective. All the other ones can stand pretty much on their own in terms of giving you card advantage, but this one need you to already have at least a few cards in hand. And if you have 9 mana, you could just start casting those cards instead. It's the most "win-more" of the Myojin, as opposed to the massive amount of comebacks the others can make.

78976: Myojin of Life's Web.author: DarthParallax
78976: Myojin of Life's Web.text_parsed:
It's really pretty scary: I THINK this might actually be the worst Myojin. That blows my mind. I could be wrong as well, but if you imagine your board state to consist entirely of

1x Myojin X (whichever one you want to test with this theory)
1x Contagion Clasp
1x That Which Was Taken
Some Lands

Then you have:

Myojin of Wrath Spamming
Myojin of Drawing Your Library
Myojin of Mind Raping
Myojin of Destroying the World
and this-
Myojin of Making an Army

Most armies will be beatable by some pretty easy to acquire board-wipe effects. Each of the Myojin you can technically play around, but it is easiest to do so against Life's Web. Red and Black are probably the hardest to 'bounce back' from. Not that I would ever want to meet ANY of the five of them on the wrong side of the table. They are monsters, each and every one.

78984: Ore Gorger.author: vantha
78984: Ore Gorger.text_parsed:
This guy would be good if Arcane was a subtype existing outside of the Kamigawa set, unfortunately it isn't. It was a modular mechanic. Other examples of modular themes were creature classes added to spells, while good in theory it was problematic and WoTc nixed it. As annoying as Kamigawa set was it was one of my favorites, because of the creature types; samurai, ninja, and spirits. Fingers crossed that we might go back to that plane some day.

As far as this card is, its great for removing all the essential nonbasic lands currently being played. But its prohibitive because you have to be playing Arcane or Spirits to do so. The 1 toughness also makes it very fragile for a 5 CC creature.

78986: Myojin of Infinite Rage.author: blurrymadness
78986: Myojin of Infinite Rage.text_parsed:
Smokebraider
Soulbright Flamekin
Koth of the Hammer
etc..

Koth himself makes this a T5 drop if all of your lands are mountains and you used no other ramping. Soulbright makes this guy T8 with no other ramp, but with other ramp could easily bring this online T4-T5.

I.E.
T2: Smokebraider
T3: Smokebraider, Soulbright
T4: Drop Myojin by using 2 mountains plus activating Soulbright's ability three times with the other 2 mountains and your two Smokebraiders

If you want easy red proliferating, use the 2 mana throne of geth so you don't need more mana on the turn you drop this guy.

78987: Time of Need.author: JaxsonBateman
78987: Time of Need.text_parsed:
Love, love, love this card in EDH, and I'm surprised it isn't more popular. There are so many awesome legendary creatures to grace each color in EDH, so for 2 mana you get to find the best one for your current situation. And given that it's only single costed in green, virtually any deck with a Gx identity, even if its 5c, can run this card.

Totally 5/5 for EDH. Probably a 3/5 for regular play; obviously fantastic in certain decks, but useless in a lot of decks.

78989: Sosuke, Son of Seshiro.author: Donovan_Fabian
78989: Sosuke, Son of Seshiro.text_parsed:
The idea is to play sosuke and sachi together granting all your snakes, shamans, and warriors benefits (ie your shamans produce lots of mana and your warriors have death touch), along with serpent skin (flash and 1/1 plus regeneration) with those warriors, which were included in the theme deck it comes in.

And yes it does work great with any type of warrior tokens, and also with cards like psionic gift since it doesn't matter how the creature is damaged only that it takes damage from creature.
78989: Sosuke, Son of Seshiro.text_posted:
The idea is to play sosuke and sachi together granting all your snakes, shamans, and warriors benefits (ie your shamans produce lots of mana and your warriors have death touch), along with serpent skin (flash and 1/1 plus regeneration) with those warriors, which were included in the theme deck it comes in.

And yes it does work great with any type of warrior tokens, and also with cards like psionic gift since it doesn't matter how the creature is damaged only that it takes damage from creature.

79080: Lantern-Lit Graveyard.author: Mode
79080: Lantern-Lit Graveyard.text_parsed:
"Yeah, because I really needed another four copies of Cinder Marsh..." -- Continue

Seriously. It's so dumb that made functional reprints of Tempest's slow lands rather than giving us the enemy-colored cycle of them in Champions of Kamigawa.
There were no real color-pairings in this this set either way, so why not go for it?

Their preconstructed deck "Kami Reborn" was , so one of them would have fit in there too.
And it contained Iname, Death Aspect, the counterpart to Iname, Life Aspect, which lead to Iname as One as one of the few multicolored cards in this block being enemy-colored. Admittedly, pre-constructed decks from Betrayers of Kamigawa and Saviors of Kamigawa with two colors had allied ones, and made use of those lands.

But still, even if they wanted functional reprints, they could have printed all color combination for the slowlands throughout that block. Maybe they even planned that, but for one reason or the other didn't.

I'd have liked to see the missing five getting printed in Kamigawa, especially if their artwork would have turned out to be as amazing as that from the cycle we got. (It's kind of their redeeming quality.)

79084: Lava Spike.author: DespisedIcon
79084: Lava Spike.text_parsed:
@ladon---
If you have 6 mana in your pool at start, this is an infinite loop.
1) spend 1RR , play Lava Spike with Desperate Ritualspliced; 3 mana left.
2) Activate the Izzet Guildmage's 2R ability in response; the copy goes on the stack, and 0 mana left.
3) You let the copy resolve: you deal 3 damage and add RRR to your mana pool. In response to the copy resolving, you spend 2R and copy the original spell, putting another copy on the stack.
4) Rinse and repeat.

I propose someone with a MTGO account go and test this, to clear doubts ;)

79084: Lava Spike.author: DarthParallax
79084: Lava Spike.text_parsed:
I've spent basically the entire day on gatherer looking up 'Red + Damage + high community rating'

As you can expect, I've seen a bazillion comparisons to Lightning Bolt. Of all the comments I've read, I've seen that more often than not if your complaint is 'this isn't as good as Lightning Bolt' then you are more likely to be a newer poster than an older one -posted 2009 or later, which coincides, coincidentally, with M10's re-release of Lightning Bolt.

I say this with confidence because I see a lot of cards like Hammer of Bogardan which look terrible by comparison get their just respect from the old vets, and oftentimes reading what they say shows me something I missed. In the case of Hammer, it was the value of being able to 'regrowth' the Hammer in the late game. Don't get me started on the jaw drop I did when Fireblast finally 'clicked'. (even if I still think its ugly and needs an art update)

In general, I think people who immediately jump to 'this isn't Lightning Bolt' are either commenting on Shock or not thinking hard enough. Most Red cards that aren't Lightning Bolt are in fact still good for something.

been building up this rant all night, couldnt find a better place to put it than under 'the almost Lightning Bolt' page.

79088: Gutwrencher Oni.author: Mode
79088: Gutwrencher Oni.text_parsed:
Blood Speaker works well with this one.
He is an Ogre, and you don't have to cast him to get an advantage out of it if you discard him for Gutwrencher's effect, since he'll return with the next Demon you cast.
Not a great combo, but possibly worth a thought for block-constructed.
(Otherwise, Changelings would help both Gutwrencher and Blood Speaker.)

Like the other oni, he's basically only on curve, however it's an easy restriction to meet with all of the playable/decent ogres out there and discarding doesn't matter if you have an empty hand. IMO, run him in
-a speedy deck (you have an empty hand),
-a dredge deck variant (you want ways to get stuff into the graveyard), or
-a demon/ogre deck as intended.

3/5 by modern day standards for good creatures, probably 3.5 then

79090: Gifts Ungiven.author: mEthidz03
79090: Gifts Ungiven.text_parsed:
Could someone please explain the ruling that you can say that you "can't find 2 more cards with unique names"

If someone gifted and only picks 2, isn't that saying that the rest of the deck is comprised of only 2 other cards, thus not being a tournament legal deck? I know that you don't have to reveal your deck to your opponent, but couldn't the opponent then call a judge saying "this guy doesn't have a tournament legal deck, if he can only pick 2 unique card names?" The judge can look at the deck and confirm that its a legal deck, thus making the "i cant find 2 more cards" impossible?

I love the idea of the shrines since they become better for each one out and you can only have one of each due to their legendary status, meaning you have to have a bunch of diffrent colored shrines to really get these to wreck your opponents. So much flavor.

Of course if you really want to utilize these shrines consider a mirror gallery to fix the legendary problem. Having just two of these out alone will give you 4 damage a turn for whatever target you have in mind.

One = 1 damage, Two = 4 damage, Three = 9 damage, Four = 16 damage.

79112: Myojin of Night's Reach.author: Mode
79112: Myojin of Night's Reach.text_parsed:
granted, but when used along with this lockdown it's worth using it.
but you overstate this card, this combo certainly does not make it 5/5.
in general, it's the worst one from the Myojin cycle.
An indestructible 5/2 eight-drop is not that cheap. and forcing an opponent to discard his or her hand in lategame is not such a tragedy as well i think, unless you can force him to do so every upkeep...
the other myojinns don't create a lock, but they are often more useful as a single card:
Cleansing Fire 4/6 --> Wrath of God except himself
Infinite Rage 7/4 --> Armageddon
Life's Web 8/8 --> Eureka for you
Seeing Winds 3/3 --> Massive card advantage
well ok, the latter isn't the best one either (they apparently over-nerved this guy during playtesting), but you will in most cases draw more than your opponent is able to discard, though.

79112: Myojin of Night's Reach.author: Bigg_ol_FATTKIDD
79112: Myojin of Night's Reach.text_parsed:
This comment section, gatherers, had made me lose a little faith in humanity.

Does no one play multiplayer games?
Does no one have the foresight to notice that this card makes all opponents discard, not just one? Or did people not care? (Except for a few of you)

Everyone, do yourselves a favor, go and play a game with four or more people. More than four even!

You'll laugh.

You'll cry.

You'll win some and lose some.

You'll see dumbtastic game states develop.
But most of all, you'll start looking at the game in a whole different way.

And that, my friends, is the cosmic prospective.

79112: Myojin of Night's Reach.author: Ligerman30
79112: Myojin of Night's Reach.text_parsed:
I have him in my EDH reanimator decklist. It fights control and combo pretty effectively. 99% of strategies are based off of drawing cards to beat your opponents in edh (even aggro needs card draw or they die). If your opponent's hand is empty at any point in the game, there is likely something really really wrong happening. This card, (Much like Karn Liberated) just stops all the bad things from happening and lets you punish your opponents for being greedy. Also, works well with Iname, Death Aspect to earn you some serious flavor points. It costs almost literally the same as Mind Twist for 7 and instead of screwing one opponent, you screw all of them. Seems fine to me. If you have him in play, you are in a very good situation. It's a lot like a black Jin-Gitaxias, Core Augur that doesn't draw you cards. It also can be used to make sure the blue player at the table doesn't do anything to you. If he does something, pop this sucker's divinity counter and everyone will kill him for his stupidity. A less mean version of this card to consider is Scythe Specter. I think the only reason this card is rated so low, is that people didn't read what it does and just saw it as an 8 mana 5/2. I'm really disappointed in you guys.

5/5 (this card is nuts)

79112: Myojin of Night's Reach.author: EvilDarkVoid
79112: Myojin of Night's Reach.text_parsed: Works wonders in a Child of Alara EDH deck. Leave the counter on it long enough to survive the dead baby, and then when everyone has next to no board remove the counter to put them into topdeck mode. Almost always wins the game. Myojin of Infinite Rage does this even better, but has a higher cmc. Note that in casual playgroups "better" can become "not fun to play against", however. Due to triple red/black in the casting cost it can sometimes be tough to get them out, though.

79115: Cloudcrest Lake.author: SquirePath
79115: Cloudcrest Lake.text_parsed:
The answer to the Why didn't the just reprint Thalakos Lowlands is;

Thalakos is a race*?* from Dominaria. Kamigawa is a different plane, the reason they did that is probably only an aesthetic one.

Quoting the MTG wiki:
The Thalakos originally lived on Dominaria, maybe with another outward appearance. During the time of their planeshift, the Thalakos were entrapped in the conflict between the Dauthi and the Soltari, despite their neutrality. All three races were caught in the maelstrom of energy that surrounded Rath, and trapped within the "Shadows," the extraplanar space between Rath and Dominaria. They were left in an incorporeal state, unable to communicate with people on either plane, yet able to see into both the Dominarian reality and that of Rath. This predicament led the Thalakos to lose their sanity.

Kinda irrelevant quote though. lol

79115: Cloudcrest Lake.author: CannotWynn

The Shocklands are a good example of this, as a Hallowed Fountain could probably be found in planes other than Ravnica.

79125: Reverse the Sands.author: tcollins
79125: Reverse the Sands.text_parsed:
The reminder text seems to have caused an awful lot of confusion, if you cast this in a chaos game with this scenario:
Player 1 Life Total: 26
Player 2 Life Total: 32
Player 3 Life Total: 3
You : 10

You redistribute the life totals, meaning one player receives a life total of 32, one receives a life total of 26, one receives a life total of 3 and one receives a life total of 10.

Might be fun to use in a {W}{B} deck that allows you to pay for card draw / advantage (Necropotence or something like Phyrexian Arena) Also would work wonders with Plunge into Darkness since you can drop your own life total down to 1, then swap with your opponent! (Hopefully getting your win condition in hand in the process!)
79125: Reverse the Sands.text_posted:

You                        : 10

You [i]redistribute[/i] the life totals, meaning one player receives a life total of 32, one receives a life total of 26, one receives a life total of 3 and one receives a life total of 10. 

Might be fun to use in a {W}{B} deck that allows you to pay for card draw / advantage ([autocard]Necropotence[/autocard] or something like [autocard]Phyrexian Arena[/autocard]) Also would work wonders with [autocard]Plunge into Darkness[/autocard] since you can drop your own life total down to 1, then swap with your opponent! (Hopefully getting your win condition in hand in the process!)

2nd to have 33,

yourself to have 43 life.

This card isn't nearly as good as people think it is, even with its real ruling.

79129: Distress.author: GrimjawxRULES
79129: Distress.text_parsed:
@Alqatrkapa & scumbling1: Since both of you clearly have a lot of money, would you be so kindly as to buy a playset of Thoughseizes too?

Okay, enough with this ridiculous nonsense. Thoughseize is ridiculously expensive, and the majority of players playing casual would never consider obtaining even a single one outside of perhaps trading for it. You guys need to respect the fact that not all players want to throw away (yes, I did just say that) 100 bucks on four pieces of cardboard.
The only place I've ever seen Thoughtseize being played is at tournaments, and many of those who use it don't actually win or even go to the top 8.
If you want to invest money in your tournament deck, fine with me, but don't just assume that every other person wants/is able to do that.

Anyway, Distress is a good card. I've seen it used to take away bombs in casual many times, and a single mana doesn't make all the difference in the world when the decks you're using isn't consistently winning on the first four or five turns.

79132: Pinecrest Ridge.author: DacenOctavio
79132: Pinecrest Ridge.text_parsed:
Compare to Kazandu Refuge and Karplusan Forest. If you're building on a budget, these are all solid lands for your {RG} deck. Consider this; Pinecrest Ridge is only uncommon, so it's not supposed to be great. But, Pinecrest Ridge, unlike Kazandu Refuge, Rootbound Crag, Stomping Ground, and Copperline Gorge, never comes into play tapped. The value is there on turn 1. And that's all {RG} decks care about.

Admittedly, I'd rather play Rootbound Crag or Stomping Ground or Grove of the Burnwillows depending on the format, but this is an ok land.

79133: Mana Seism.text_parsed:
What do all of you mean? This card is a great finisher! Think about this:

You have 12 Mountains on the battlefield, this and Banefire in your hand. You tap all your lands, that's 12 red mana, then pay 2 to play this, sac all your lands, for another 12 mana. That is 12-2+12=22 pure mana right there! Pay one for Banefire's CMC, then pay the rest, 21, on it's X cost... uncounterable and unpreventable 21 pure damage right at the opponent! Combo this and other mana accel cards and you would have a catastrophe! If you just use Banefire alone you would only get 11 damage.

79145: Hundred-Talon Kami.author: DoctorKenneth
79145: Hundred-Talon Kami.text_parsed:
The thing with Soulshift is, on one side of the coin, there are few other abilities that would fit so well with ghost-like representations that duck in and out of the fabric of reality, playing with life and death like Homer Simpson playing with a hospital bed. It is deliciously flavourful. The dream is, of course, to have a steady stream of spirits. Whenever your foe kills a kami, another rises to replace it.

In practice, that simply does not happen. First, kami come in all five colours, which means there is no solid, in-block way to get them to the graveyard. No reliable sacrifce effects, no other (solid) graveyard interaction. That means we're relying completely on your opponent to pop these things- and if they don't want you to get a certain spirit back, they won't let you. Five colours also means you're either going to speard yourself thin, or deny yourself some of the soulshift tech in the colours you don't play. Compare to infect. Infect is seen on black and green, primarily, with some supporting technology in blue. This focuses the deck considerably. A good infect deck can even be mono-coloured, but the options exist for it to splash, and splash well. The same cannot be said for soulshift. It spreads itself too far. Kami, as representations of a wide variety of concepts, needs to be represented across colours. But it takes a mechanical hitto do so.

Finally,the soulshift mechanic often does exactly nothing. Often, your creatures will die into an empty graveyard, and frankly, when an otherwise overcosted creature like this with soulshift 4 or so bites the dust and gives no returns, you feel ripped off. And that's just not fun.

79149: Hisoka's Guard.author: Tiggurix
79149: Hisoka's Guard.text_parsed:
Funnily enough, Hisoka himself is much less useful than his guardians. I guess they are his bodyguards for a reason.

Anyway, they are fine for protecting your Goliath Sphinx or whatever you want protecting. A cool little combo I've thought up to accompany them is using a Rings of Brighthearth while having out a second Guard. Activate their abilities on each other and copy up to two times with the rings, and you have two Shrouded Hisoka's Guard and up to two other creatures which are also protected from any Lightning Bolt or Terror. Of course, this would cost, in total, (6)(U)(U), so there are almost certainly better alternatives out there.

79151: Devouring Greed.author: Elvoran
79151: Devouring Greed.text_parsed:
This card is my bomb in my Red/Black Spirit Deck.

The idea is to sacrifice all Zuberas with it, as it's part of the cost you sacrifice them when paying for Devouring Greed which puts their effect in first and then Devouring Greed's.

So if you have 4 Ember-Fist Zubera and play Devouring Greed you deal 1*Zuberas*Ember-Fist Zubera damage + Zuberas*2 damage and gain Zuberas*2 life.

79151: Devouring Greed.author: blurrymadness
79151: Devouring Greed.text_parsed:
T1 - Tortured Soul
T2 - Nether Traitor, Swing for 2
T3 - Swing for 2, Spectral Procession
T4 - Swing for 5, use this for 12

A perfect 20 on T4! All evasive. Works well with Dark Triumph as well. Lingering Souls in the same deck works well.

T3 could instead be lingering souls, T4 be flashback souls, drop Nether Traitor, sac one token to dark triumph, attack for 15 evasive and have a blocker.

Use Death Denied to come back from sweeps and from this card.

Lots of ways to end the game quickly with a spirit aggro deck, even if half the cards are from kamigawa.

79151: Devouring Greed.author: surewhynot
79151: Devouring Greed.text_parsed:
In my opinion, one of the very best cards available to any Spirit deck running black. Many spirit decks, especially the ones that can run black (Orzhov spirits anyone?) can generate a healthy number of spirits. But it really does NOT take that many spirits to make this card absurd. Obviously you have to be smart about when to play it, because getting caught with your pants down leaves you with a lot less spirits and a wasted spell. In most cases though, it will prove to be"game-ending" good.

Take this very likely scenario:

T1: Lantern Kami

T2: Wicked Akuba/Bloodghast/Another Lantern Kami and Spiritual VIsit/Beckon Apparition (some combo of those). Swing for 1 with the Lantern.

T3: Lingering Souls. Swing for 3 more damage.

T4: Swing for 5 more damage, play Devouring Greed. Opponent loses anywhere from 10-12 life and you gain that much. That can be the game, right there.

EDIT: Or, look at blurrymadness...Same idea.

79158: Ragged Veins.author: Mode
79158: Ragged Veins.text_parsed:
It's actually not even that bad in general, in fact i would consider this to be a very joyful addition to a Core Set.
It's simple, yet can help players learn why making use of instant-speed can be that advantageous.
If you play it within combat you'll be able to have you opponent lose two life, plus he'll possibly refrain from greatly using his creature in future turns.
And this card could of course awaken the inner Johnny of new players, which can't combo around that much with simple starter cards most of the time.
I know i'm ranting a lot right now, but this just seems to be the perfect Core Set card to me.

Besides, it's a buffed reprint of Binding Agony!

I agree that this is perfect for a core set. Its almost like one of those instants "until end if turn, whenever target creature..." but actually simpler. Would be great for teaching new players how to use flash for combat tricks. Even if some nub uses it the completely wrong way, it's still close to pacifism in effect, so they won't just dismiss the card out of hand. If that isn't the poster child for core set, I don't know what is.

I like this art, but it would probably have to change for a core set (needs to be more generic). Sad to think that they would probably abandon this "elegant but creepy" look for something more overtly "look, I'm bleeding, how evil is that?"

79159: Honden of Cleansing Fire.author: Donovan_Fabian
79159: Honden of Cleansing Fire.text_parsed: I love hondens, as long as you can keep them out on the field without getting destroyed they are devastating to an opponent, and being enchantments you can benefit from any card that works with enchantments like enchantresses or etc.  They are quite possibly some of the most powerful cards in the game if you can get a number of them on the field at once.  Its possible to run a deck that can play all 5 since you will note no honden takes more than 1 of the color mana it needs.  Personally, I find the honden of cleansing fire, and honden of nights reach to be the two most interesting of the honden cards.  Cleansing fire can keep your life points up even when your taking a beating, if you have even 2 hondens on the field it gives you 4 life a turn.  Nights reach forces your opponent to discard cards, which after 2-3 turns can leave them without being able to draw anything and keep their card for more than the end of their turn.  Even if you only play 2 its worth it, but 3-5 is practically instant game win.  Another thing to note is the hondens steadily go up in mana cost starting with the honden of infinite rage (3 total, the next consecutive shrines jump to 4 and then 5), the trick is to play the lowest mana cost one first if you can, and work your way up.

79159: Honden of Cleansing Fire.author: Voriki
79159: Honden of Cleansing Fire.text_parsed:
This is I think one of the most underrated shrines there is. I play a shrine deck with 4 Enduring Ideal. Once you get a few shrines out while dealing damage with Infinite Rage and getting a few blockers with Life's Web, gaining 6-10 life per turn becomes insurmountable on the other side. Plus I don't think it makes sense to look at one shrine at a time. If you're using anything less than 4, maybe 3, then it makes no sense to use them at all.
5/5 on this shrine, for easily getting me up to 100 life on several occasions against several different and powerful decks.

79166: Blood Speaker.author: Voriki
79166: Blood Speaker.text_parsed:
This card is absolutely insane. If demon based decks (or decks simply using a decent amount of them) are a flame, this guy us pure gasoline. It's so nice to play him, sac next turn for an Abyssal Persecutor then play him again next turn and tutor for something equally as nasty like the new Desecration Demon. A demon every other turn without even needed a land draw for 8 turns is a wonderful thing. All this with only 1 of them out! Not to mention death effects being triggered or having a recurrent creature that can be used as a sacrifice if the need arises.

4 mana to put any demon in your deck right in your hand is an underestimated edge with this card. Even without Kaalia he is a staple, in my opinion, for any demon deck.

Plus he has a decent power to be a blocker as well. Great card, great ability, demonic fun for everyone!

79166: Blood Speaker.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
79166: Blood Speaker.text_parsed:
The very cool Deathrender combo works because Blood Speaker's ability is triggered, not activated. The sacrificing is not a cost, it happens only when the ability resolves.

1. On upkeep, choose to sacrifice Blood Speaker, who is equipped with a Deathrender.
2. After the ability resolves, you have a fine demon in your hand, and Blood Speaker is safely in your graveyard. Deathrender's ability then goes on the stack.
3. Deathrender's ability allows you to put the demon from your hand to the battlefield and attach Deathrender, then the Blood Speaker jumps back to your hand (you aren't even required to cast the demon!)
4a. Cast Blood Speaker, then attach Deathrender. That's , your only mana cost for this turn, and you get to do it again next turn! I recommend using Heartless Summoning to cut that cost by .
4b. If you have a free or cheap way to sacrifice the demon, just leave Deathrender equipped, then sac it on your opponent's end step to get back the Blood Speaker for free. Protip: Oni of Wild Places and Spirit of the Night are the only two demons who naturally have haste.
