[b]3.[/b] Deathrender's ability allows you to put the demon from your hand to the battlefield and attach Deathrender, then the Blood Speaker jumps back to your hand (you aren't even required to cast the demon!)
[b]4a.[/b] Cast Blood Speaker, then attach Deathrender. That's [5][B], your only mana cost for this turn, and you get to do it again next turn! I recommend using [autocard]Heartless Summoning[/autocard] to cut that cost by [2].
[b]4b.[/b] If you have a free or cheap way to sacrifice the demon, just leave Deathrender equipped, then sac it on your opponent's end step to get back the Blood Speaker for free. Protip: [autocard]Oni of Wild Places[/autocard] and [autocard]Spirit of the Night[/autocard] are the only two demons who naturally have haste.

79176: Honden of Seeing Winds.author: DoctorKenneth
79176: Honden of Seeing Winds.text_parsed: @Colossus: Shrine is not a creature type. It is an enchantment subtype, thus the changelings would not have it, and no extra effect is gained. Currently, there is no way I can think of to apply the shrine subtype to any other permanenet, even other enchantments. You can turn the shrines into creatures. 79176: Honden of Seeing Winds.author: endersblade
79176: Honden of Seeing Winds.text_parsed:
These shrines cost far too much mana to be of any benefit in a normal 60 card deck. However, I have the Blue, White, and Green one in an enchantment EDH deck, and they are extremely effective. Gain 6 life a turn, 3 1/1 Spirits, and draw three cards. Not to mention the benefits of them being enchantments in an enchantment deck.

Thing is, yes, by themselves they are rather worthless. I'd rather play Howling Mine/Font of Mythos or even Heightened Awareness over this. But being together is what makes them strong.

79176: Honden of Seeing Winds.author: Aquillion
79176: Honden of Seeing Winds.text_parsed:
@Verdande: I think you misunderstand. The card is itself a Shrine, so even just on its own, it makes you draw one card a turn.

This card isn't bad. Usually the cost for drawing a card every turn in blue is 4 (Archivist), but this requires less blue commitment and is less vulnerable to removal. In any decent deck, if you get it out and keep it out, this will win you the game all on its own. Sure, it's not the absolute most aggressively-costed card drawing ever, but it's not bad at all, especially in a deck with either Honden of Infinite Rage or Honden of Night's Reach, the other two decent shrines. Since you probably only want to run one of each, you're not likely to get them all out at once; but they're decent enough on their own to be worth it.

79179: Minamo, School at Water's Edge.author: nammertime
79179: Minamo, School at Water's Edge.text_parsed:
Fortify with Darksteel Garrison to pump any creature for +1/+1 for each extra blue mana you wanna spend every turn.

Courtesy explanation: Target itself to untap while fortified, so that when it taps, it gives +1/+1, then it untaps itself thanks to its ability.

Note: You can target it, since the only required property of the target card is that it's a legendary permanent. The target can be tapped or untapped.

1 Tolarian Academy

3 different Artifacts of your choice

- Tap Academy for {U}{U}{U}{U}
- Spend {U} to tap Minamo to untap Academy ({U}{U}{U} floating)
- Spend {U}{U} to tap Candelabra to untap both Academy and Minamo ({U} floating)
- Spend {U} to tap Minamo to untap Candelabra ({0} floating)
- Tap Academy for {U}{U}{U}{U}
- Spend {U}{U} to tap Candelabra to untap Academy and MInamo ({U}{U}) floating)

It should repeat itself here for as much blue mana as you need at this point, if my calculations are correct.


Annoying to set up, but it would be awesome to see it work.

79179: Minamo, School at Water's Edge.author: CuriousThing
79179: Minamo, School at Water's Edge.text_parsed:
In Modern, this cycle is by far the closest R&D has ever come to developing nonbasic lands strictly better than basic lands. According to Mark Rosewater (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/mr65), being nonbasic isn't considered a large enough drawback to factor into the "strictly better" discussion -- so, it comes down to whether being legendary is enough of a drawback.

That's highly debatable. If a blue deck has even one tappable legendary permanent it should switch out one Island for one Minamo without a second thought. The first Minamo is strictly better than an Island. It's just a question of the second, third, and fourth Minamos.
79179: Minamo, School at Water's Edge.text_posted:

That's highly debatable. If a blue deck has even [i]one[/i] tappable legendary permanent it should switch out one Island for one Minamo without a second thought. The first Minamo is strictly better than an Island. It's just a question of the second, third, and fourth Minamos.

79180: Honden of Life's Web.author: Aquillion
79180: Honden of Life's Web.text_parsed:
The weakest shrine; this should have cost 4 instead of 5 -- the shrines needed to be priced at a cost where they're moderately useful even alone, and this one isn't quite there.

It's still nice, but the problem is that in order to make good use of the tokens it produces you need support, and in order to get a decent number of tokens you need support from another shrine (preferably more, since having only two in your deck is unlikely to work and having multiples of a legendary can cause problems), so you probably need support to get out the second shrine... and at that point, there are much simpler options for token generation.

79186: Shizo, Death's Storehouse.author: Kryptnyt
79186: Shizo, Death's Storehouse.text_parsed:
@TheGoodDoctor20
What's wrong with using Skittles as a general? It's much more tame than plenty of things, consider for a moment that infect can't capitalize on other player's work, he's monoblack which limits his options, and he starts at around turn 6 without accel. He doesn't net you tons of free cards like many generals do, and he's not as aggressive as generals like Rafiq, Uril, or other common "general damage" generals. He's not even the best infect general I've seen, The Mimeoplasm is far scarier in that regard, since he's liable to one-shot you out of the game. You don't see monoblack decks abusing the life buffer in order to set up tutors and combo out on you that often, like blue decks often do. All in all, it ends up being a fair game, at least that's my experience playing against him. If he's too fast and you're not having fun, that's on you to improve your deck... or to convince the other people at your table to dogpile!

Horrible. Not just regarding flavor.

As if a casting cost of 4 wouldn't have been expensive enough for such an effect like this, you have to pay 1 mana for every single damage to redirect it to you only? That's just terribly arkward.

Overall this card is pretty much unplayable.

79199: Vassal's Duty.author: Tiggurix

The most awkward card I've ever seen, for sure. You, a planeswalker, a being of immense power, able to warp time and reality itself almost at a whim, and one of the few beings able to walk between the many, many worlds of the multiverse, is a vassal to the very creatures you summoned into being!?

And not only that, the card is practically useless. 1/5, at most.

@nibelheim_valesti: The fact that you can summon and bind these 'proper authorities' to your will should prove that it is rather they who are the vassals in these matters, yes? It doesn't matter if you press these creatures into your service by way of magic or respect, as it is still you, the planeswalker, who exerts dominion. And by the way, it is quite obvious that the players are not brazen "neowalkers", but rather the near omnipotent beings that were the planeswalkers from before the events of Time Spiral block.

79205: Eiganjo Castle.author: sarroth
79205: Eiganjo Castle.text_parsed:
@tavaritz: You seem to have misread Stone Rain's flavortext It clearing states Eiganjo Castle was still standing, but does not state it was ever hit by the fire, rock, and rage of the spirits described in the text; just that it remained. You are assuming that means it was hit and survived the destruction, but it could also mean it was never the target, that the targets were everything else.

I'm not a fan of legendary lands. Some like this have good abilities, but I don't like accidental land destruction when someone else plays this forgetting I had one of my own in play. This is why Wizards now prints cards like Emeria, the Sky Ruin, which would otherwise have been legendary, without the legendary supertype.

79217: Isamaru, Hound of Konda.author: Zetan
79217: Isamaru, Hound of Konda.text_parsed:
@Eved

Most of the people idolizing this card are EDH players. Being a Legend is a drawback in every other format, but in EDH, as the general, it's a huge advantage. First, he can be played almost anytime, which means he's on the table first turn 99.99% of the time, and very rarely leaves the table for long. Second, generals deal special damage that can never be healed and kills twice as fast.

That means as an EDH general, this guy is more like a 4/2 that doubles all bonuses to power from enchantments/equipment. Oh, and damage he causes can never be healed (though it does count as half as effective when combined with normal damage). Plus, he bounces from your graveyard to your hand, can never be affected by anything while in your hand, and is guaranteed to start in your hand in addition to your other 7 cards.

If all that were written on the card, you'd call him 5/5 as well.

I agree, he's a solid 4/5 in any other format, but he's an easy 5/5 in EDH.

@Eved

Second, generals deal special damage that can never be healed and kills twice as fast.

That means as an EDH general, this guy is more like a 4/2 that doubles all bonuses to power from enchantments/equipment.  Oh, and damage he causes can never be healed (though it does count as half as effective when combined with normal damage).  Plus, he bounces from your graveyard to your hand, can never be affected by anything while in your hand, and is guaranteed to start in your hand in addition to your other 7 cards.

I agree, he's a solid 4/5 in any other format, but he's an easy 5/5 in EDH.

79217: Isamaru, Hound of Konda.author: Enelysios
79217: Isamaru, Hound of Konda.text_parsed:
If you play this as an EDH general you are probably the most boring player alive. (Or FearSomeCritter) He is not a great general for general damage. He may get a few hits in on the first couple turns but once he is killed and you need to pay 3 for him again you will feel silly. He has no other utility, he is just a cheap, white, vanilla.

Outside of EDH (or at least not as a general)? This hound is a powerhouse. don't underestimate what a 2/2 for one can bring you early game.

79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.author: Mode
79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.text_parsed:
Let's just call it "Untaidake, the Fail Keeper".

Here are five reasons why you should not play this card:
1. Enters battlefield tapped
2. You have to pay 2 life each time
3. It only produces colorless mana
4. Its mana can only be cast for legendary spells
5. The card itself is legendary

So you get a land with delayed use that can only be outside once which requires you to spend high amounts of life while on top of this only produces mana with very restricted use which also does not help to manage color issues at all.
Oh, and you can't use the mana for activated or triggered abilities either.

Yeah, that's indeed pretty much the worst land ever printed.

What where they thinking when designing and/or playtesting this card?!
It manages to make Chimney Imp appear rather playable.
Even in a legend-themed block like Kamigawa, this card is hardly worth playing with half the amount of restrictions.

What a pity John Avon's artwork was wasted on such an awful card...well, possibly it was intensively chosen as a little comfort to prevent people from crying when they see this card for the first time.

It would possibly have seen play if it entered the battlefield untapped and produced two mana of any colors without requiring to pay life each time.
This way the card would have been powerful, but still not broken either.

79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.author: Mickacabra
79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.text_parsed:
I actually gave this 1/5 instead of 0.5/5, for one reason: Commander. In Commander/EDH, many of its drawbacks are undone by the nature of the format.
1: The fact that it's legendary is about as much of a drawback as any other legendary permanent in a singleton format.
2: The fact that you have to pay 2 life is much less of a drawback in a format where your beginning life total is 40.
3: Even if its mana can only be used for Legendary spells, it can at the very least get your general out of the command zone and onto the battlefield a turn quicker.
Those three facts are worth half a point to me.

79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.author: Baconradar
79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.text_parsed:
The great insult here, the TRULY great insult, is that this is a RARE.

With cards like One with Nothing you can argue it is a johnny card. Some Johnnies will love the card. It is also extremely elegant design.

But that isn't true of this card. It doesn't even do anything interesting. It has ok flavour, pretty nice art, but that doesn't excuse it. It's miserable and it's insulting to the poor kid who pulls it as their rare. At least as an uncommon, though it would come up more, you could kinda live with the loss. But some customers can't afford lots of boosters and a card like this is a slap in the face to them.

79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.author: DarthParallax
79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.text_parsed:
I went back and forth in my mind from 0-3 stars, and nearly gave it more.

See, the thing is, the only cards to compare this one to are considered mistakes by Wizards.

It produces 2 mana, it costs 0 to play.

Mana Crypt produces 2 mana and costs 0 to play, with almost similar drawbacks. Restricted, Legendary, what's the difference? (If it's not, it should be.) Mana Crypt is busted.
Sol Ring produces 2 mana and costs 1 to play, and it's way more busted than Mana Crypt can ever be, having literally no drawbacks.

The Signets produce 2 mana and cost 2 to play! And Wizards considers them a little overpowered- and..they're right! The Signets make your deck hum like every card in it is hybrid. Actually not too much for Constructed- for once, mana bases were FUN to build! :D But too much for Limited. So they say.

Ancient Tomb produces 2 mana, costs life to use, and is 0 to play. It's the flip side of Mana Crypt, with Sol Ring on the equal and opposite side. Guaranteed drawback, or chance drawback, or guaranteed no drawback. Ancient Tomb we can argue about, but it's in the Vault. It's probably above what Wizards is comfortable with.

This land is indeed just plain worse than every card I named- but considering how great those cards all turned out to be, it makes sense that Wizards was too worried to let this come into play untapped.

Paying life for mana or limiting what that mana can be spent on are not new- in fact, cards like Ancient Ziggurat get made very frequently. The only thing it's even reasonable to not like here is entering tapped when the card is already Legendary. There were enough good Legends that a new Ancient Tomb would have been great.

2.5 Stars, for working with so many necessary constraints and because Amulet of Vigor exists, which turns this into a 3.25 star card. :)

79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.author: TheWrathofShane
79218: Untaidake, the Cloud Keeper.text_parsed:
I would use it in a legendary deck. 2 Life is not bad, tapped is a hindrance. The real downside is it cant tap for for other things. But if thats what most of your deck contains, its playable.

Legendary Decks are not something I would play expecting to win every game. Just a deck with singleton copies of a bunch of legendary creatures.

And this land is not bad at all for commander. If you commander ever gets sent back to the command zone, well this can pay his extra fee on its own.

This is not the worst card in the world. You don't want to include this in your land slot. Think of it as a free spell that takes a land drop, that you can use the next turn.

And then, there's this.

Thankfully, I've purchased a total of 800 bulk rares, and none of them were this. I got Gargoyle Castle and Contested Cliffs though, which aren't great, but they're certainly better than this!

There are just too many restrictions, because wizards rightfully worries about lands that tap for more than one mana. A land that taps for for legendaries would be cool. Even with the two life, it would be cool. But coming out tapped really makes it too slow and conditional. Colorless EDH can use this because... they have limited options. Everyone else can stick with lands that tap for colorless the turn they come out and do better. This card isn't good, or fun or interesting.

That said, its better than Sorrow's Path, not sure why it is rated worse. This is the worst rated land on gatherer.

79219: Hair-Strung Koto.author: Kelrath
79219: Hair-Strung Koto.text_parsed:
"The artwork on this card makes no sense in relation to the card's effect. Why is the woman playing the koto slipping into dementia and bleeding instead of the swans? "

This Koto produces a mind-wracking sound, eliminating thought and making it impossible to concentrate. It's this effect that correlates to the milling effect.

The swans appear to be rebuked by the sound, and the woman is the one playing it. It would make sense that her prolonged exposure to the Koto is forcing her into dementia.

Additionally, anyone saying that this card is too expensive is simply insane. The {6} cost of this card could translate to "You win the game." if played right. cards like Tome Scour and Memory Sluice are cheap, but only come around 4 times in a single deck, and require four draws each. With just one draw and enough tokens, you could win the game as soon as this spell resolves.

In my opinion, this is the single most powerful mill card i've seen yet. Still not convinced? Play it in a deck with Mycoloth, then come back to me.

79219: Hair-Strung Koto.author: allmighty_abacus
79219: Hair-Strung Koto.text_parsed: Tokens and milling are to perfectly fine win conditions. When they intersect, however, things go horribly wrong. Suddenly you can't chump block or just win via overrun as you are either tapping or saccing your tokens to some mill engine. And tapping creatures to mill is simply far less efficient than other proper mill cards. Not to mention it reduces how many chump blockers you have.

79219: Hair-Strung Koto.author: Japicx
79219: Hair-Strung Koto.text_parsed:
It's hard to sing this card's praises when I know about Altar of Dementia. The Altar is simply more efficient, and considering that it costs 4 less mana makes it pretty much strictly better. It requires sacrifice of creatures, but you can easily make that a good thing. If you're making lots of tokens, the most common form in black (a color found in nearly all mill decks) is 2/2 zombies, which means twice as much milling as the Koto, not to mention that you can attack with the Zombies and then sacrifice them later. And if you're playing with a mill deck, you're running a lot of blue, so you can take control of your opponents' creatures. Their Blightsteel Colossus has just swung at them, milled them for eleven cards, and is somewhere in their library. That's efficient problem-solving right there.

The only advantage that the Koto has is that it works well with untapping shenanigans.

79219: Hair-Strung Koto.author: Stinga
79219: Hair-Strung Koto.text_parsed: @ Kelrath I fully agree with you on the flavour. Masterfully done. As to the card's actual utility however... I am afraid I must refute you here. Creature dependent mill suffers from some problems as an archetype in general and the Koto exemplifies this issue. Mixing creature-win stratagems and mill-win stratagems is inefficient. Note I am not saying the likes of Hedron Crab or Nemesis of Reason are bad. I count them as "pure mill" cards. I.E cards (regardless of type. Artifact, creature, whatever) that exists solely to mill someone. One would not put Hedron Crab in a beatdown deck, for instance. The Koto relies on having a large amount of creatures on the field. Using it with a crab or two would be...less-than-effective. Now here's the kicker: token makers are not mill cards, such the aforementioned mycoloth. As a lover of saprolings, I can tell you Mycoloth can win the game if it sticks around a turn and it will do it without the help of a Koto. Instead it punches someone in the head REALLY HARD. Damage is simply far more effective at killing someone than milling is, as one damage is 1/20th of a win while 1 mill is 1/about 50th of a win (this is why mill cards like glimpse the unthinkable tend to work with much higher numbers. It compensates for this and, consequently, makes the cards powerful even if you only cast one. It works with the rest of your deck. Complaining about them is like saying a red burn spell that hits for roughly five damage to the face for two mana is bad because you may only draw one). You are asking me to more than half the effectiveness of the killing potential of my creatures, and that is before you account for the synergies we will be skipping by going the mill route. Mycoloth synergizes with other token-friendly cards like Thelonite Hermit and Overwhelming stampede, not with the likes of Keening stone. I suppose what I am saying here is that damage and mill do not stack. Any card (Like this one) that relies on the other (Like mycoloth) to function is simply inefficient as you must kill an opponent in more ways than one. That said, the Koto makes an ok sideboard for turbofog-type things and is certainly interesting. I would run it in a deck with the likes of undead alchemist or Oona, Queen of the Fae for a cool, mill swarm. But it would not be a mill deck. It would be an undead alchemist synergy deck.

79226: Horizon Seed.author: MrQuizzles
79226: Horizon Seed.text_parsed:
It is overcosted, but a lot of people seem to misunderstand the rules for regeneration.

Regeneration is a shield that lasts until end of turn. That shield replaces the next destruction event to happen to that creature with the removal of all damage marked on the creature, removal of the creature from combat, and tapping the creature.

You can play spirits and sorceries during your main phase and put those shields on your creatures for your combat phase. It's actually a pretty good effect.

79231: Tenza, Godo's Maul.author: allmighty_abacus
79231: Tenza, Godo's Maul.text_parsed:
If I were ever in a situation where I had to make an improvised club from a log, I certainly wouldn't name it. I mean, it's a log. It's going to rot eventually. And even before then the chain will break. So what does he do with the next one? Does that become Tenza II? Hehe, sounds like some cr@p 80s action movie series. Tenza II- Godo's Retaliation, Tenza III- Godos' Vengeance, Tenza IV- Godo Bloody Godo.

Oh yeah, the card itself sucks. If you don't have red or legendary creatures out, it's just an overpriced legendary leonin scimitar. If you have a legend out, it's a total of 4 mana to give a creature a continuous giant growth. If you have a red guy out, it's 4 mana for a trampling scimitar. And even if you have a both ridiculous conditionals met, you just have a creature with +3/+3 trample. What if that creature gets blasted? Have fun trying to equip it to something else and getting a no doubt tiny effect.

Run Colossal Might instead. Sure it's an instant, but you can bluff with it. On any creature.

79233: Journeyer's Kite.author: ClockworkSwordfish
79233: Journeyer's Kite.text_parsed: Overpriced, (much of Kamigawa block is) but you'll never need another mana-fixing ability. Plus, it's colourless, making its great mana-fixing available to all decks. it's valuable in 5-colour decks since, while green and its land-searching is technically available, there is no guarantee that you will initially draw any forests. This is the best land-fixing WUBR will get.

79233: Journeyer's Kite.author: Baconradar
79233: Journeyer's Kite.text_parsed:
Definitely good in casual slow decks. One major benefit that people don't realise immediately is that this lets you thin your deck out, so you don't draw dead lands. Not only that, but it is self powering - you need a lot of mana to use it, but once you've used it a few times, you certainly have that mana to spare.

In fact with something that allows it to untap, like say a voltaic key or an elder druid, it can end up pulling all the land out of your deck.

Not too powerfu, just a good solid card.

79233: Journeyer's Kite.author: Gabriel422
79233: Journeyer's Kite.text_parsed:
This saw some play in mono-white control back in the day. Those decks literally finished with Storm Herd, and this was a reliable source of card advantage.

As for myself, I like this card. Nowadays Wizards dislike something that requires you to shuffle every single turn, though I found joy in doing so. It's the joy of a wizard thinking, how far do I still have to go until I have seventeen lands in play and every card I draw then will mean business?

79233: Journeyer's Kite.author: Kruggles

I run this in a Mikaeus, the Unhallowed EDH deck, and with things like Cabal coffers this wins games. Guaranteed land drop every turn is a very nice thing, and insane card advantage as well as deck thinning. After you have activated this 5-10 times the chance of getting that Gauntlet of power or Plague Wind is much higher.

But any other format it is near-useless. five mana investment for one land tutor is too much, and eight for 2 land is terrible in comparison to cards like Armillary Sphere

79242: Ryusei, the Falling Star.author: Fire_Master
79242: Ryusei, the Falling Star.text_parsed:
Ryusei's abilities are the abilities you would acpect to find in a red card. Also they comply with an unwritten rule for red cards, that rule is RISK. When Ryusei dies it deals 5 damage to eery creature withou flying including your own.So in the end you risk losing your own creatures as well. Red has many powerful creatures but many of them require a sacrifice. Take Rathi Dragon for example, it comes into play for 4 mana and it's a 5/5 flier but you have to sacrifice 2 Mountains to keep him otherwise he dies. It's the same with Ryusei.But do not forget that great power comes at a great cost. That's the rule that will always follow many red cards.

You are right Donovan but you have misunderstood me. I didn't losing your creatures, I meant the sacrifices tha many red cards require.
Something like Sharpnel Blast and Rathi Dragon

Time for a design story!

As Aaron Forsythe recounts (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af38); Ryusei and Keiga, being in more dragon-centric colors, were allowed to be the most splashable, and as the dragons moved further and further from colors that most typically have dragons, they became that much less splashable, ending in the very green-centric Jugan.

79247: Reach Through Mists.author: Zuty
79247: Reach Through Mists.text_parsed:
@Kryptnyt - It's the only target, so yes. If any of the spell's targets are illegal when it goes to resolve, the entire spell is countered and none of its effects happen. Splice basically adds on the effect of the card onto the card being cast. So you are paying {1}{U}{R} to Draw a card and deal 2 damage to a creature or player.

But if you Splice Glacial Ray, Consuming Vortex, Blessed Breath, Goryo's Vengeance, and Kodama's Might onto Reach Through Mists, as long as the spell has at least one remaining legal target, it resolves and does as much as it can.

~Zuty

79247: Reach Through Mists.author: UsagiYojimbo
79247: Reach Through Mists.text_parsed:
It cantrips, it thins your deck, it's the cheapest Arcane card out there! That means it splices too!

Thaaaaaat's right, all that fo just One Blue Mana! Worried about card advantage and board position? Say no more, act now and we'll throw in Glacial Ray so you can build your own Electrolyze... but that's not all!

Do you love Divination, but hate tapping out on your own turn?!
Act now and we'll throw in a free playset of Everminds so you can draw two cards the way we used to, after leaving mana open to counter and bounce!

BUT THAT'S NOT ALL!

79252: Forbidden Orchard.author: Mode
79252: Forbidden Orchard.text_parsed:
By itself this land is rather one of the worse WUBRG/paradise lands, but it has great combo potential and often lets you turn the drawback into a further advantage:

Nine-Ringed Bo seems to be the most obvious way to kill those guys, but isn't really worth using since you won't be able to make further use of this artifact, thus only resulting in card disadvantage.
But either the combo mentioned by crenel with Æther Flash (and Repercussion) works nice,
or Goblin Sharpshooter to get rid of them (and other 1/1 chump blockers),
Avatar of Might can be used for reducing its cost by {{6}},
Sheltering Ancient to provide creatures for its cumulative cost,
Biomantic Mastery for some extra cards,
Congregate/Divine Congregation for some extra life,
Mana Echoes for mana accel - given that you're running a spirit deck,
Netherborn Phalanx/Stronghold Discipline for some extra lifeloss,
Retaliation to make the spirits less useful as chump blockers,
or make use of their cip(/enter the battefield)-trigger:
Carnival of Souls for {B} and the further cost of 1 life,
Intruder Alarm to create several loops along with a third card, e.g. by animating this land,
Lethal Vapors to kill them immediately,
Poisonbelly Ogre to let your opponent lose one life,
Mantle of Leadership for a +2/+2 buff of the enchanted creature,
Portcullis to get rid of them without any possibility for them to return,
Tainted Æther to get rid of them - once again - or even to force him to sacrifice another creature or a land if you are able to destroy them before this ability resolves, e.g. by using the aformentioned Sharpshooter.
Of course you can then again make further use with graveyard triggers,
Toshiro Umezawa will be able to copy instants in your graveyard,
Black Market provides more black mana,
Burning Sands to make your opponent sacrifice his lands,
Deathgreeter, Soul Net and Dross Harvester for lifegain,
Dingus Staff, Vicious Shadows or Hissing Iguanar for damage,
Inheritance to draw cards by paying {{3}},
or Sadistic Glee, Rockslide Elemental, Scavenger Drake, Algae Gharial, Kresh the Bloodbraided or Deathbringer Thoctar for +1/+1 counters on the accordant creature.

Whew.
This should be most thinkable cards to combine with that land i listed here.
I left a few really useless cards out, but as you see there are lots of possiblities, it's up to you how to handle that colorless Spirit token.

I personally love the card (including the artwork).
I guess now you know why - Johnny approves! ;)

79252: Forbidden Orchard.author: AssKickingBoots
79252: Forbidden Orchard.text_parsed:
This card is okay in alot of 3+ color decks, especially one's with some kind of pinging or big enough creatures you don't give a damn. It's solid mana fixing. However, situationally, in the right deck, this is killer.

I just ordered 4 of these to add to a deck built around Varchild's War-Riders (another way to force opponents to gain creatures) and Suture Priests (to gain life and force opponent's to lose life for taking on creatures) along with other similar cards (Soul Warden, Soul's Attendant, Blood Seeker). As has already been mentioned, Goblin Sharpshooter is a great way to get rid of the chumps (with a Basilisk Collar on he'll get rid of almost everything without shroud or indestructibility... or pro red). Forbidden Orchard will mana fix my tri-color deck (white, red, black), while making my deck less dependent on drawing the War-Riders.

5/5 in a deck built for it, still probably a 4/5 in just about any other deck that needs mana fixing. I'll compromise and give it 4.5/5.

79252: Forbidden Orchard.author: yyukichigai
79252: Forbidden Orchard.text_parsed:
Lots of fun combo potential here. Æther Flash has been mentioned of course, but it's always fun to put this into decks where 1/1 creatures don't really matter. Lightmine Field decks, Peacekeeper decks, anything running Urza's Armor... lots of mildly humiliating possibilities. It's also a surprise winner for Pestilence/Pyrohemia, where you can either use the one mana you just produced to kill of the creature that just came into play, or disregard the mana and use the spirit token as a way to keep your enchantment on the board.

I'm also very, very happy that the creation of the spirit token is a separate ability and not a cost. That way if your opponent is using something like Ivory Mask or Leyline of Sanctity you aren't screwed out of a land because they can't be targeted.

79256: Pious Kitsune.author: DysprosiumJudas
79256: Pious Kitsune.text_parsed:
This card is severely underrated. Yes, it requires you to have another card in your deck. Luckily, that card is so good (i.e. three mana for instant color protection at any given moment) that you'd run it in a lot of white decks anyway. So when you're running Eight-and-a-Half-Tails, which many times you generally just are in the first place, this card can be a powerful auxillary. Sure, it takes a while to rev up (which, granted, pretty much takes it out of the running for any DCI-managed Legacy games), but you get this thing running into the late-game and you'll be getting a ridiculous amount of life every turn. Eventually it just reaches a point where your opponent really just can't hit you fast enough to stop your rampant lifegain. But the real kicker of all of this is that your opponent can't even Bolt your Pious Kitsune or do any other such nonsense, as for a mere three mana your Eight-and-a-Half Tales can make Pious Kitsune have protection from whatever color it is that is trying to screw with you. And after the two mana kick-up, all it takes is just one mana for each spell, so if they try to double bolt you, it's just an extra mana to stop the second one.

So is this card incredibly narrow? Yes, yes it is. Is it also only viable in casual decks? Of course. But is it still a great card when its put into the right deck? You bet your Jace it is. Trust me, when this card does its thing, well, it can be one of the most ridiculous lifegain operations out there. Not a 5/5, but it is definitely a shame to have it so maligned.

79857: Nezumi Bone-Reader.author: Mode
79857: Nezumi Bone-Reader.text_parsed:
"Sorcery clause kills it, since you can't easily sack things already headed to the grave." -- Tanaka348

Agreed. They should have loosened the activation restriction to: "Use this ability only during your turn."
This way, it would still have been impossible to abuse his ability as a soft lock to prevent your opponent from drawing any more cards, yet you would have been able to 'recycle' creatures that would have died anyways.

He might still find some use in token decks, particularly rat tribal.
As Fadingstar said, he works well with Marrow-Gnawer.

79863: Reweave.author: Mode

Reminder text of new keywords is often omitted on rare cards since they are often more complex than commons or uncommons, which are more likely to be found in a booster and will help with that.

Aside from that, given that one manages to find some useful Arcanes to splice this card on, it should actually do a good job when "topdecking" your desired cards with Visions' Tutor cards.
When saccing cards which have accordant triggers like Academy Rector you can get even more out of the effect.

80241: Orochi Hatchery.author: DaLucaray
80241: Orochi Hatchery.text_parsed:
Hmm, I'me have a hard time thinking about the cost and reward for this card. Let's see the numbers without counter shenanigans.

Cast for {2} - {5} for a 1/1 boost. I suppose it's batter than The Hive

Cast for {4} - {5} for two 1/1's. I would say this is about the same power level as The Hive, a vanilla 2/2 is worth about a 1/1 with evasion.

Cast for {6} - {5} for three 1/1's. When you're still comparable to The Hive, you know you're not that good. Clearly this card was not meant for an aggro format. Fortunately the Orochi are pretty much the only tribe that can come close to Elves in raw mana accel.

Cast for {8} - {5} for four 1/1's. We're entering casual only levels here. For an initial investment the size of Akroma you get a Goblin Rally with a less supported card type (granted, if you use a five-mana card in goblin tribal you are doing it terribly wrong) each turn. I imagine it gives you a pretty consistent board presence in a format like casual EDH, where 8 mana is midgame.

Cast for {10}- {5} for five 1/1's. Well hatchery, you're finally cost-p/t efficient. If you can't win with an Increasing Devotion each turn you're going to have a hard time winning.

Cast for {12} - {5} for six 1/1's. Now THIS is what Urzatron is REALLY for. Did you think it was about Colossi or Eldrazi? Nope. The best thing to do with that is get a Conquerer's Pledge each turn. Six snakes man! Six of them! Also, past here we don't gat any sorceries with the same cost and same token number.

Cast for 14 - {5} for seven 1/1's. Hey, did you know that no card has ben printed with the mana cost of {14} colorless mana anywhere on it? We have reached the point where there are no applicable sorceries, but a Symbiotic Wurm dying has the same effect. Pretty neat.

Cast for {16} - {5} for eight 1/1's. The closest thing we can get to this effect is Sekki, Season's Guide, but you usually don't get that effect all at once. Beyond here we get very, very few symbols for these numbers.

Cast for 18 - {5} for nine 1/1's. There is nothing that specifically makes nine 1/1 tokens, or nine or anything, I believe.

Cast for 20 - {5} for 10 1/1's. Yay, the number of token is now twice the cost to summon them!

Cast for {100} - {5} for 50 1/1's. Dang, those Orochi must be getting busy. If you can't win with 50 power on the board each tun, you're probably in a position where you have 100 mana to spend. You'd have just gotten milled out in EDH, for cripes sake! Unless you just want to have a cool win-con in your infinite mana deck, why?

Cast for {1000000} - {5} for 500,000 1/1's. Hmm, that or choosing all targets for all spells? Decisions, decisions...

From this, I'd say that the nursery is definitely meant for mana accel and/or lategame. For best results, use in a Sachi, Daughter of Seshiro Shaman EDH deck. The power in this card is versatility; I wouldn't play it if it was stuck in any one mode, but it's still powerful. I feel that making the activation cost {4} or {3} wouldn't have made it too broken. All in all, a meh card.

80242: Psychic Puppetry.author: Lateralis0ne
80242: Psychic Puppetry.text_parsed:
Rather interesting. Twiddle for all permanents, and I like that it can hit enchantments, as well. Sure, there's only one enchantment that taps on its own, but still, the ability to do so makes it awesome. The {U} Splice cost makes it relevant and useful in-block, as well. A decent card all the way around. It's not as good as some other cards of its type and style, but it'll give combat tricks in a pinch, as well as tapping key artifacts and lands.

3.5/5

80250: Through the Breach.author: AlicanC
80250: Through the Breach.text_parsed:
A ramping deck can cast this on turn 3 to bring Emrakul and ask the opponent to sacrifice more permanents than he has.

And guess what happens to your sacrificed Emrakul and other cards you wasted? They all go back into your library so you can do this all over again.

As a bonus, you automatically counter all mill decks.

Fun, fun, fun.

80254: Sachi, Daughter of Seshiro.author: Donovan_Fabian
80254: Sachi, Daughter of Seshiro.text_parsed: This card can be a huge help producing green mana, or just about anything if you can get it out on the field. Attach to it any card that untaps a creature card, such as freed from the real, or instill energy, and she can produce 4 or more green mana turn along with any other shamans you might have. Its arguable whether this is a better set up than using druids who can also pair up to produce different kinds of mana, but it certainly helps. The orochi sustainer, orochi leafcaller, sakura-tribe scout, and sakura-tribe springcaller, and shizuko, caller of autumn are all snake shamans that can benefit from this card as well as any snake gaining the + to defense such as coiling oracle. For green/red decks soulbright flamekin is an elemental shaman who can produce an extra 2 red mana if you spend 6 on it initially to give creatures trample.

80274: Zo-Zu the Punisher.author: ddong
80274: Zo-Zu the Punisher.text_parsed: Why are people talking about casual anti landfall decks? Who plays anti landfall as an archetype? Is landfall totally dominating your local meta? This card hits them for every land they play, its good against control decks which want to drop a land every turn. A red deck should get an opponent down pretty low by turn 4 or 5 and this makes it harder for control players to stabilize since each land brings them closer to Lightning Bolt range. Granted its not all that great but he was not designed to be anti land fall, so he shouldnt even be compared to Tunnel Ignus.

80275: Desperate Ritual.author: Tommy9898
80275: Desperate Ritual.text_parsed:
The not broken way to use it is to play it with other arcane like Lava spike on turn 3, splice with the spike so you have 3 mana and just use it to play something, like a Shinen of Fury's Fire. The net result being on turn 3 in mono red you did 3 damage and got a 2/1 haste critter, so it puts you ahead in tempo and you can use it again later.

The dumb way to do it is in all in red, empty your hand turn 1 or 2 and playing one big creature like deus of calamity.

The way to break it is with Djinn Illuminatus so you keep replicating it, then cast a big fireball.

80275: Desperate Ritual.author: markarmor
80275: Desperate Ritual.text_parsed: @Tezz - If you have an Izzet Guildmage in play, a Lava Spike and a Desperate Ritual in hand and 5 mana available, you form an infinite combo. Cast the Lava Spike, Splice the Desperate Ritual onto it, then hard cast the Desperate Ritual. Allow the hard cast Desperate Ritual to resolve then respond using the 3 mana from it to activate the Izzet Guildmage's spell copying ability, targeting the effect of the Lava Spike spliced with the Desperate ritual. Allow the copy to resolve (netting you 3 mana and 3 damage via the Lava Spike with splice Desperate Ritual copy) and respond again with a copying of the original effect which is still on the stack, repeat ad nauseum for an infinite loop and infinite damage. You win, but no one will want to play against it much.
80275: Desperate Ritual.text_posted: @Tezz - If you have an [autocard]Izzet Guildmage[/autocard] in play, a [autocard]Lava Spike[/autocard] and a [autocard]Desperate Ritual[/autocard] in hand and 5 mana available, you form an infinite combo. Cast the Lava Spike, Splice the Desperate Ritual onto it, then hard cast the Desperate Ritual. Allow the hard cast Desperate Ritual to resolve then respond using the 3 mana from it to activate the Izzet Guildmage's spell copying ability, targeting the effect of the  Lava Spike spliced with the Desperate ritual. Allow the copy to resolve (netting you 3 mana and 3 damage via the Lava Spike with splice Desperate Ritual copy) and respond again with a copying of the [i]original[/i] effect which is still on the stack, repeat ad nauseum for an infinite loop and infinite damage. You win, but no one will want to play against it much.

80275: Desperate Ritual.author: Hepatizon
80275: Desperate Ritual.text_parsed:
People who compare this to Dark Ritual unfavorably make me sigh.

1. It's not from Alpha, it's from Kamigawa. The fact that Dark Ritual has been reprinted so many times is still amazing, considering its ridiculous power. The fact that Desperate Ritual is even close to it is absurdly powerful for Kamigawa.

2. Desperate Ritual is Red. It shouldn't be exactly the same as one of the defining cards in black, any more than Black should have something identical to Lightning Bolt.

3. It has splice. "Ho hum I don't use splice" you say. This card alone makes it worth trying. Your dark ritual goes away, this doesn't have to.

4. Any number of things can shave that off of it. There are far fewer things that make a dark ritual free.

5. This is legal in modern. Dark Ritual isn't.

Yeah, it's not gonna get your Phyrexian Negator or Phylactery Lich out on turn 1, but it will allow you to respond with a Ball Lightning on turn 2, and that's not bad.

80278: Iname, Death Aspect.author: SubstantiaNigra
80278: Iname, Death Aspect.text_parsed:
With cards like Bloodghast and Nether Traitor, you don't even need anything like Living End or Patriarch's Bidding to make Iname, Death Aspect's ability viable.

That being said, there must be something deeply satisfying about watching your 5 stars (Jugan, Keiga, Kokusho, Ryusei and Yosin), your Shadowmoor block spirits (yes Figure of Destiny and 5 CMC Demigod of Revenge and co. spirits, I'm looking at you), your Kamigawa block spirits, or your Obzedat, Ghost Council and friends come out of the graveyard all at once. Unless your opponent has mass removal and the mana to pay it, pulling this trick off will mean game over 9 times out of 10.

Iname also allows you to play that Karador, Ghost Chieftain you had in your hand, as early as turn 2, and for just . This guy can then help you selectively cast all those spirits sitting in your graveyard. This of course works best with spirits of lower CMC, but with 375 spirits in MTG, there's plenty to choose from. Your opponent's playing affinity? Cast Kataki, War's Wage. Your opponent's playing control or enjoys his removal spells? Look into splashing some and including Kira, Great Glass-Spinner in your deck. Otherwise, you can always go back to the old-school Unearth for those rare instances where your low CMC spirit's mana cost is a bit tricky. Similarly, you can use other reanimation cards such as Reanimate and Exhume for the fatties (e.g. Karmic Guide). Not saying is a bad idea, though (with cards such as Drogskol Captain, Guiding Spirit and Geist of Saint Traft out there).

This style becomes even more interesting when combined with any of the 44 "Whenever you cast a Spirit or Arcane spell..." spirit creatures. You could gain card advantage with Infernal Kirin, put more lands in play with Loam Dweller, search for auras with Tallowisp, or gain life as your opponent loses it with Thief of Hope. You can even start filling the battlefield with tokens via Baku Altar. There's plenty of cheap spirit spells capable of taking advantage of this mechanic (all the Rusalkas, Glitterfang, Kami of False Hope and Nether Shadow, to name a few).

All of this while you take advantage of the spirit cards in your graveyard with the from the more recent Innistrad. 10 spirits in the graveyard? Pay and gain 20 life with Gnaw to the Bone. 8 spirits? Cast an 8/8 Boneyard Wurm for only and double its power/toughness with Wreath of Geists for just an additional . 4? Get 4x 2/2 wolf creature tokens with Kessig Cagebreakers every time you attack (see Spider Spawning as well).

As you can see, the possibilities are endless.

80281: Cranial Extraction.author: Wusanderz
80281: Cranial Extraction.text_parsed:
Well Extirpate is definitely strong in that it costs less to cast, but it can only target the gy, so it should be used when you're making your opponent(s) discard, otherwise the Extraction is better.
Don't overlook Meddling Mage as an alternative though. Although the mage is susceptible to destruction unlike Extirpate and Cranial Extraction, it works in Control and will give the opponent 4 more dead draws, unlike Extirpate and Cranial Extraction, which thin them out of the deck.
80281: Cranial Extraction.text_posted:
Well [autocard]Extirpate[/autocard] is definitely strong in that it costs [3] less to cast, but it can only target the gy, so it should be used when you're making your opponent(s) discard, otherwise the Extraction is better.
Don't overlook [autocard]Meddling Mage[/autocard] as an alternative though. Although the mage is susceptible to destruction unlike Extirpate and Cranial Extraction, it works in [(w/u)] Control and will give the opponent 4 more dead draws, unlike Extirpate and Cranial Extraction, which thin them out of the deck.

80282: Iname, Life Aspect.author: VoidedNote
80282: Iname, Life Aspect.text_parsed:
Ahhhhhh... one of the corner stones of my sacred combo.

Turn X: Iname, Death Aspect, choose ALL creatures in your library.
Turn X+1: Death Denied, naming Iname, Life Aspect, Myojin of Life's Web, and Hana Kami.
Turn X+2: Play Hana Kami then sac it. Bring back Death Denied and use it to obtain other creatures and Hana Kami again.
X+Y: Repeat above until nine mana is accumulated.
Turn Judgement Day - 2: Play Iname, Life Aspect... and get it killed ASAP, possibly with Doom Blade or retarded attacking.
Turn Judgement Day - 1: When Iname dies, bring ALL creatures to my hand, wait for my opponent to stop questioning my intelligence "You realize you'll have to discard a lot of those right?". Play Myojin of Life's Web, and remove the divinity counter. Play everything.
Turn Judgement Day: Swing with every creature in my deck.

It's good, but on its own it lacks. Need to build a game plan like the one above.
3.5/5

@BuffJittePLZ I mean are able to spend 9 mana to cast .

80282: Iname, Life Aspect.author: Falgorn
80282: Iname, Life Aspect.text_parsed:
My version of it, that I recently pulled off:

1) Have three random Spirits, Lifespinner and That Which Was Taken onto the battlefield.

2) Cast Iname, Life Aspect.

3) At the opponent's end of turn, sacrifice the random Spirits to activate Lifespinner's ability and let Iname, Death Aspect "step forth". Iname will proceed to bring all the Spirits in your library to your graveyard, except of a Myojin of Life's Web or two.

4) At any point until your next turn (preferably in response to an attempt to board sweep), activate Lifespinner's ability by sacrificing itself along with the two Aspects of Iname. Exile Iname, Life Aspect to bring every single spirit in your graveyard to your hand.

5) Have Myojin of Life's Web step forth, and use That Which Was Taken to put a divinity counter on it. Especially satisfying if done in response to a Wrath of God variant.

6) Remove that divinity counter to put every single Spirit in your hand onto the battlefield.

7) Next turn, attack for a couple hundreds of damage.

8) ???

9) PROFIT!!!

Turn 3: Crucible of Worlds, Amulet of Vigor, Hedron Crab, tap/sac Hickory, play terramorphic again. grab another island, play another Hedron Crab. Play terramorphic again, grab another island, play another Hedron crab. Play terramorphic again. Another land. Mill for a total of 70 cards. Win = Yes.

80283: Azusa, Lost but Seeking.author: Ferlord
80283: Azusa, Lost but Seeking.text_parsed:
The thing with Azusa is that she isn't a giant target like all other EDH generals, at least in my play-group.

One uses Kaalia, one uses Animar, another uses Verdeloth, one more uses Niv-Mizzet, and I use Azusa. Who do you think, out of those, is going to be Chaos Warped? Not Azusa.

Getting out lots of lands for a mono-green deck is just second nature. It'd be like countering Harrow or Explosive Vegetation: all you'll be doing to stirring the sh*t around.

I can say, however, that Azusa works wonders with Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary. Any time I have him out, the game doubles in speed for me, and thus is why he's banned as a commander.

80283: Azusa, Lost but Seeking.author: Havens
80283: Azusa, Lost but Seeking.text_parsed:
@ desolation_masticore

There is a more efficient way of playing that out, also assuming if you are on the draw here.

T1: Land, Birds of Paradise
T2: tap bird+land for Lotus Cobra.
Drop a fetch, float 1, fetch, float 2, tap for mana, play Azusa
Drop 2 more fetches, float 2, fetch twice, float 2 more, tap both for mana.

Assuming you are on the draw, that's 6 mana with 2 cards left in hand on Turn 2.

Now, if you dropped something like Magus of the Future, you'd have a very interesting next couple of turns. Especially if it's followed up with something like Scouting Trek

It's odd that this and Trickbind don't see Modern play. I mean, Fetchlands run rampant (thus their $35-$50 pricetag), and there's this odd deck strategy called... what is it? Sputterpin? Wiltertwin? Splinterwin?

Whatever it is, it's based around activated abilities.

Some other cards that may be played in Modern that would get screwed are Fulminator Mage, Grim Lavamancer, Isochron Scepter, Qasali Pridemage, Celestial Colonnade, Figure of Destiny, Liliana of the Veil, Lotus Bloom, any Transmute spell like Muddle the Mixture, Deathrite Shaman, Mangara of Corondor, Knight of the Reliquery (brownie points here), Glen Elendra Archmage, any equipment, Kiki-Jiki...

80413: Soratami Rainshaper.author: Enelysios
80413: Soratami Rainshaper.text_parsed:
I love how expressive her art is! Very dynamic.

Though she looks weak at first glance, she can be a pretty solid creature in the right deck. A 2/1 flying body is not bad, even for 3 mana, but its not extraordinary. Its interesting that she is offensive leaning. All the moonfolk give tempo-loss as a cost for their abilities, luckily some of them have abilities that are actually worth paying for, abilities that are normally not put on creatures without having to tap. Instant speed shroud is one of those. The threat alone that you can activate this to protect something on your field is a powerful deterrent. is a bit costly, but I run her alongside training ground. Most moonfolk have costly colorless abilities, and I think some mana acceleration is necessary for any moonfolk deck.

The moonfolk are also a great Johnny tribal, bouncing lands is one of those drawbacks that is begging to be exploited. Lands that produce more than one mana, lands with 'enters the battlefield' effects, landfall, 'moro' or 'wisdom' effects. There are a lot of possibilities.

80509: Ashen-Skin Zubera.text_parsed:
@fibonacci112358

Strictly better than Black Cat but comparing to Ravenous Rats is different because they work differently.

Pros: One more toughness, synergy with other zubera.
Cons: Afraids of exile and bounce effects as it's effect won't happen.

My thoughts are whether to use this instead of Rats in Pauper MBC. I'll have to test whether the one toughness difference (as this is the only black zubera) is worth the risk of losing value to exile and bounce effects.

Magic player's first world problems.

80509: Ashen-Skin Zubera.text_parsed: This guy is a great defensive creature - it really makes your opponents think twice before attacking once you have other Zubera creatures out too.  I've used all five of the original Zuberas to dominate multiplayer games with shenanigans.
80509: Ashen-Skin Zubera.text_posted: This guy is a great defensive creature - it really makes your opponents think twice before attacking once you have other Zubera creatures out too.  I've used all five of the original Zuberas to dominate multiplayer games with shenanigans.

80509: Ashen-Skin Zubera.author: DarkonCrack
80509: Ashen-Skin Zubera.text_parsed:
@HuntedOlesser

Actually, not strictly better than Black Cat. Black Cat causes random card discard which is significantly better than your opponent having the ability to choose. That and you cant' factor out the Cat's creature type either which is more relevant as a zombie. While yes, Ashen-Skin Zubera is better in a dedicated Zubera deck, Black Cat is better in a deck just splashing discard as an alternative to Ravenous Rats or as a solid two tap in a Specter Deck. All on preference though.

Anyways, solid card. I have a casual 5 color Zubera deck with nothing that's higher than a 2 drop. Just draw and drop Zuberas and drop the occasional fog and/or Pyroclasm :D Definitely not competitive, but great fun casual deck. People debate swinging at me in multiplayer games :)

80525: Jukai Messenger.author: marmaris74

@Imperialstonedragon
Challenge Accepted:

Firstly, 4x Adaptive Automaton and 4x Brass Herald.
Between Serra Ascendant and Rune-Tail, Kitsune Ascendant, I can see a "30 or more life" theme, so I'd put in 4 of each of those as well as 3 Pride Guardians, 2 Venerable Monks and 4 Lone Missionaries. I'd also use 4 Heroes' Reunions just to be safe. (And why not 4 Chalices of Life, also?)

80526: Ethereal Haze.author: Ashrubel
80526: Ethereal Haze.text_parsed:
@Vedelken_Arbiter: The card does not mention Combat Damage, It says damage dealt by creatures.

This prevents ping effects such as that caused by Quicksilver Dagger. This can stop combos that revolve around a creature pinging, or a big nasty that has alternate effects when it swings or defends.

But, to answer your question directly, Combat damage is reserved strictly for damage dealt by creatures, but only during the combat damage step, and only as a result of blocking, or not being blocked. So it is nearly impossible for a permanent to deal combat damage if it is not a creature.

I could imagine a number of scenarios that can cause this card to be cast as part of a triggered effect during the combat damage step. Then I could imagine a number if effects that revert a creature back to a former state after it's damage has been calculated, but before the game leaves the combat step. These situations involve triggered effects destroying things that create creatures from other permanents, such as lands or enchantments, via static effects. See Opalescence. Again though, i cannot imagine a scenario where these effects could cause such damage to be able to be prevented, as the damage would either have already been dealt, or already be countered from the permanent no longer being a creature.

Tldr; No.

80527: Nature's Will.author: PrimeSonic
80527: Nature's Will.text_parsed:
@Donovan_Fabian
I'm sure you meant Double Strike, but that would also be incorrect. Under the new combat rules, once you go to deal combat damage, it's dealt immediately. So you could not cast any instants or activate any abilities between First Strike damage and normal combat damage.

As for the card, oh good lord how I came to hate this one (when I saw it on the other side). Recommended for any heavy hitting green deck.

80527: Nature's Will.author: wolfbear2
80527: Nature's Will.text_parsed:
@ Ruztyz and PrimeSonic: You are both wrong, Donovan_Fabian wins!
See, if a normal creature and a first striker both go unblocked, they will both trigger Nature's Will seporatly. You see this magical "combat damage doesn't stack" rule also makes for a inbetween step that spells and abilitys can be played. It's why you can block a 5/5 Scute Mob with an Vampire Hexmage and kill it. You let the first strike damage go through, than you have time to sac the Hexmage to remove the counters and kill the Mob before it even deals it's combat damage.

81702: Kodama's Might.author: GrimjawxRULES
81702: Kodama's Might.text_parsed:
Definitely underrated. Has the potential to be better than Giant Growth a lot of the time, especially in spirit/arcane decks. Consider for example cards like Kodama of the South Tree.

Something that I never really realized before now is the synergy between the "bad" mechanics of the Kamigawa block. The "hand size matters" mechanic pairs really well with the Splice into Arcane mechanic, because you're essentially playing multiple cards with the use of one, thus generating card advantage and getting more out of the "hand size matters" cards. The only bad thing was that the Arcane and "hand size matters" cards were mostly underpowered. The concept was brilliant, but the cards lacked a bit more punch, so I sure hope we get to see the return of these mechanics if the block gets continued (as with Scars), only a bit more buffed.

82000: Strange Inversion.author: scumbling1
82000: Strange Inversion.text_parsed:
Very cool art, but the fun ends there.

There were not enough decent Arcane and Spilce cards to make the mechanic work; the cards were either horribly overcosted, or so narrow that you only wanted to use them in limited. Dampen Thought decks worked when the decks started 'pre-milled' of twenty cards, but didn't make the jump to Standard. Kodama's Reach and Cranial Extraction saw some play, but not with anything being spliced onto them. Coming right off the tail of the ridiculous Mirrodin block meant that the mechanic needed a strong push to have any chance at all, and Wizards didn't give it one.

It seemed like such a waste to create a whole keyword ability just for Limited. If they ever decide to revisit the mechanic, they could potentially save it. However, they're going to have to do better than what they've done with the present set of cards. Let's see an effect so narrow as Strange Inversion's be free to Splice.

85106: Brothers Yamazaki.author: DarthParallax
85106: Brothers Yamazaki.text_parsed:
How to fix the new M14 Legend Rules for Brothers Yamazaki.

First, the only format that we can fairly say needs any errata is 2HG. Whatever WOTC says for non-THG, let WOTC have their silly way. In 2HG though, screw WOTC because their answer isn't going to be appropriate for the flavor of Brothers, and we all know it.

Here is The Brothers Yamazaki Rule for 2HG:

"First thou shalt cast another Brothers Yamazaki from thy hand until the number of Brothers Yamazaki on the battlefield be four. Four is the number of Brothers Yamazaki there shalt be and the number of Brothers Yamazaki there shalt be shall be Four. Thou shalt NOT have Three Brothers Yamazaki unless thou proceededst immediately to Four. Two is too few, and Five is Right Out!"

85106: Brothers Yamazaki.author: MrChimzar
85106: Brothers Yamazaki.text_parsed:
If the card stands as is with the new Legendary rule, the "fun" happens as follows:

If you and an opponent each have a Brother nothing happens, as it always has been. However, whenever a player plays another brother, it would see three on the board and the player with two would have to sacrifice one. More interestingly, if a player has two brothers and his or her opponent plays one, one of the original two would be "legend ruled" So, clones can still "legend rule" this card in a way.
